description:
Super small place, but super goooooood! I was apprehensive in trying this restaurant, but I'm glad I tried it with my friends. The food is good and the servers are friendly too. 

I ordered the Sisigsilog, which look to me like ground & shredded chicken. It was a little bit salty, but I liked how it was presented on a hot plate. The lemon went well with the dish and wasn't too overpowering. The meal came with some garlic rice and a fried egg. That garlic rice is the bomb!

I also tried the Shangsilog, which comes with some Lumpia (egg rolls). It's good...wouldn't say it's the best though. I'd recommend this dish if you're indecisive though because the flavors aren't too complex.

Since it's a pretty small place, it's easy to miss it. I think there's a minimum of $15 before being able to use a credit card. I wish the portions were bigger, but the price is inexpensive...so I can't complain.
author: Victor L.

description:
Rating: 3/5; would come back if a friend wanted, but not on my own

Small cozy place with a laidback environment and very homey food. Reasonably priced for an SF spot, but while the food was okay it didn't stand out. The logsilog was good but unremarkable. The lumpia in the shangsilog was disappointing since they were so small and light on filling. I was expecting more of the satisfyingly meaty ones I was used to from my Filipino friend's family gatherings, nearly double the size of the ones I got here. The garlic rice was nice and hearty though. The ube macapuno pie lacked texture and flavor on the other hand, probably would not try dessert here again. 

Overall a good spot to get a solid but basic plate of food. Doesn't really qualify for the criteria that I look for in a restaurant though, offering things that I would be unable to replicate at home.
author: Edward R.

description:
Loved this little spot. Once you can find it (I think I passed it a few times while I was searching for it) you'll probably appreciate trying out this place. I got in from an afternoon flight, checked into my hotel, and was on the hunt for food. Saw this place listed on Yelp, looked through a few pictures of the food and was sold. The place is tiny, has great prices for being in San Francisco, has a variety of tasty looking food...what more could you want? 

The good stuff:

Daily special (pork belly) - I didn't really know what I wanted but the server mentioned the daily special and it sounded like something I'd enjoy. It was fried pork belly with a side of their rice topped with a fried egg. It was simply great to have a hearty meal after a full day of traveling. It's what I'd imagine true, authentic Filipino food to prepared and served like. 

The pork belly was delicious (along with the sweet sauce they serve with it). My only gripe was that it was a little more fatty than I'd like...and yes, I know pork belly is typically fatty. Other than that I thoroughly enjoyed everything.
author: Eddie K.

description:
V popular place for late night sisig. Recommend the food. HOWEVER THERE WAS A VERY RUDE MAN HELPING TO WORK THE WINDOW. HE WORE GLASSES WITH TINTED SHADES and threw the most amount of shade at me. I asked nicely hey can I use your restroom. He said VERBATIM "yes we do but it's in the back and it's for employees only." Like what kind of response is that. You're in the SERVICE industry. Did someone hurt you?? Who broke your heart?? Jeez that got me so heated. Do the words "sorry we don't have one" not exist in your vocabulary???

But then I ate the sisig and had another beer and I felt better. It's a super small space so expect to wait and make awkward convo with your date whilst waiting.
author: Ashley S.

description: What a gem in the heart of the city! First time Ive ever eaten Filipino food- so I can't tell you how authentic it is.. But Really enjoyed the food here and like how small and intimate the restaurant is. (More casual and they seem to do tons of takeout) Most dishes are served with garlic rice (omg!! Sooo good! And I'm usually not a rice fan) with an over-easy egg. The chicken sisigsilog was super flavorful. Friend ordered spam which actually didn't taste too bad. Also tried the noodle dish under the specialty items which was also good. Enjoyed the rice dishes more though. Finally we had the purple yam pie and it didn't look like the one on yelp. ;( Guess they changed it a bit as there is no topping anymore. Everything tasted good and very different to most things I've tried before... came back within one week!
author: Christina I.

description:
Food is the bomb! Simple and delicious. 

Came here on the basis of Yelp recommendation, just a block from my hotel here. The place was seemingly full - but a single chair shyly beckoned me in. The other diners appeared to be regulars. 

No tables, just a bench facing the kitchen and prep area, and another facing the wall. The server was welcoming and on my admission that I'd never been there before, she pointed me at the sisigsilog which came with sides of garlic rice and a fried egg. 

The meat arrived sizzling on a platter and was nothing short of delicious. Greasy, meaty, salty and just a hint of charcoal/burning. This is hangover food for sure. I flipped the egg over into the garlic rice and dived in. 

Sitting next to me was a diner who revealed his part-Filipino heritage and made recommendations for other dishes to try - particularly the Lumpia Shanghai, which look like small crispy egg rolls. He conceded that the sisigsilog was the best thing here. 

I'll be back.
author: Richard L.

description:
Taking a break from drinking, this spot is the one! Came here at the recommendation of a friend before we ventured out to Emporium barcade. Hole-in-the -wall spot...literally! Walking past, blink and you miss it. What they lack in space, they make up for in amazing food. 

We were seated on the counter facing the kitchen so you can see their process of cooking. We ordered the bangsilog and the lechon kawali daily special, plus the pancit palabok. Pancit palabok was okay, just your average. But OMG the bangsilog, which is a deep fried baby milkfish, was so crispy and moist. It's my favorite meal ever and they did it so good. The lechon was so crispy and savory, I'm drooling just thinking about it. And it comes with garlic rice and an over easy egg?! AMAZINGGGGG!

Drunk or not, I'm definitely coming back when I'm in the area!
author: Cheney E.

description:
Tiny spot in the Tenderloin with delicious Filipino food. The menu doesn't look like much, because most of the dishes are essentially just variations of rice and meat. But the food is so good, and just feels comforting.

It's not a fancy place, and definitely not somewhere I'd bring a group of friends or bring someone visiting from out of town. But I'd go here any day I'm looking to eat some tasty, hot, and comforting food for ten dollars.

As a note, I think the credit card minimum if $15, so make sure to bring cash (or just order more for the next day!)
author: Kedar V.

description:
Have to go to SF for yummy Filipino comfort eats. (looking at you Atlanta)

I'm so glad I stumbled on this place after about 30 mins of indecisive "what to eat" wandering around. San Francisco is a foodie heaven and there were so many spots I wanted to try. Thank goodness I walked up on Jones St to this little treasure.

It's a tiny sliver of a spot but they do have a walk-up window. There's about 12 seats inside but they serve things up quick. A menu full of various silogs and a few other Filipino specials and apps. I went with the Sisigsilog which seems to be pretty common for first timers here. Chicken cooked in a lemony, garlicky, soy sauce, and jalapeño concoction (could use more heat if you asked me but you can add to it). YUM. All of the silogs come with garlic rice and an egg. And if you're a weirdo like me who doesn't like runny yolks (hush), they'll cook it a bit harder for you.

It's comforting and finger licking delicious. I also tried the buko pie which I ate so fast I wondered if I actually ordered it. 

I had to visit again as my Last Supper in SF and had the sisigsilog again but added on a side of the milk fish. The milk fish was OK to me but still tasty, just small. I do like that they let you add on another protein for only 3.99. On that note, the pricing is such a relief in the sometimes very overpriced SF. Great value for what you get.

Bonus?? They're opened til 3am on the weekends. (looking at you Atlanta)
author: Tamera B.

description:
It was 12 a.m on Saturday and this place seemed promising. There's barely any parking so be prepared to walk to your destination or pay $15 for the parking garage across the street. The place was a cool hipster hole in the wall place. Service was 5/5. We ordered to go but ended up dining in which was fine to the workers. Also it is overpriced in my opinion. We payed $25 just for two orders. 

We got our orders and it looked very delicious and it looks good on pictures. We ordered a tapsilog and noksilog. I don't know if it was the time of day, but the garlic rice on the tapsilog was drenched with the soup of the beef tapa. It looked more like adobo than beef tapa. The taste was unpleasant as it was overpowered by the sweetness of the beef tapa. The chicken of the noksilog was good but very dry. Overall there are way better tapsilog places to try. Again I don't know if it was the time, but I'd rather make tapsilog at home.
author: Loraine H.

description:
I got the spamsilog and a slice of buko pie and both were to die for 

I went on a Tuesday evening at there was no wait. My two friends and I were seated and helped within 5 minutes! There's limited seating and it's all bar style, but it's cute and convenient. 

I love spam so spamsilog ($8.99) was perfect for me! If you normally don't like spam/salty food, this might not be the best choice for you. The spam is served with two slices of cucumber and garlic rice topped with a sunny side up egg! So delicious!!

My friends got the sisilog ($10.99) and it was to die for  The meat is served seperate from the cucumbers and garlic rice topped with egg that constitutes the "silog" part of the dish. Pro tip: squeeze the juice from the lemon slice all over the meat before mixing the meat with the garlic rice to eat! The lemon flavor is a game changer 

The buko pie slice ($4) was soo creamy! I didn't expect to enjoy it as much as I did. My slice was served fresh and straight out of the oven. Seeet but not too sweet. Despite not being a huge fan of pies, I would probably order this again.

The location of Tselog isn't the best, as it's in a central part of the Tenderloin. Walking to get here, you'll probably see needles/used needles on the ground and lots of homeless people. Regardless, I'd make the trek to Tselogs again forsure. 

Thanks for serving me some of the best Filipino food I've ever had! Can't wait to come here again :)
author: Kaitlynn L.

description:
This is a really cool tiny restaurant and it's fun when you sit facing the cooks because you can watch your meal getting made. My boyfriend and I love filipino food. We ordered two meals and I think it would've been a better idea to share one because we ended up needing a to go box. The pork belly won rice was delicious!! The tocilog on the other hand was really dry so it didn't taste as good as other Filipino restaurants. 

The employees are super attentive and our food came out fairly quick. There are also outlets so you can charge your phone. 

There's filipino music playing which was chill and after we ate our food we just chilled in here for about 10 minutes before walking the steps hills of SF. 

I would recommend trying this place
author: Sarah A.

description:
I was walking by when I saw maybe 5 empty seats and there were no line at around 6 PM.
okay, let's give this place a try ..

I ordered "Lumpia Shanghai" but they were out.
let's try again ..
I ordered "Arroz Caldo".
the porridge was good, the texture was dense but not gluey.
it was a well put together and I was quite surprised actually that it was better version than the Chinese version.
this is something that I recommend.

I also ordered "Sisigsilog".
a vibrant dish that came on sizzling hot skillet and full of flavor,
and it's the type of food that really goes well with rice.
luckily, all of the Tselogs comes with garlic rice and egg.
the chicken was tasty and with a squeeze of lemon on it? ..
Golden.
author: Rudy H.

description: This little spot was a big surprise for me. I really enjoyed my dinner here. The place itself is tiny and has a bar area for seating. It can maybe fit about 10-12 people inside. The service was great as I was greeted right away and the guys working were super friendly and helpful. I had the Sisigsilog which was chopped chicken seasoned with lemon, soy sauce, and onion sitting on a hot plate. Dish also comes with egg and garlic rice. The dish was super flavorful, juicy, and delicious. Prices were also great and very affordable for the quality of food you are getting. This place has a very authentic feel and you can tell everyone working here have a passion for the food and culture.
author: Steven J.

description:
Came here randomly when visiting SF, a couple of friends and I were just looking for places to eat. We were not disappointed. Tselogs is delicious! 

When we walked in we didn't know what to expect. This specific location was very small. Parking sucks in that area but your best bet is the meter parking on that street. 

I ordered the tapa (sweet beef) and Bangus (fried milk fish) You usually get one meat with your silog (fried rice and egg) but for a few bucks extra you can add extra meat. The tapa was delicious and always love bangus. The rice was amazing and you can't go wrong with an egg on top. My frend got the chicken sisig and it was amazing too. They have other Filipino meals there too like lumpia (filipino egg rolls), arroz caldo (rice porridge) and others! 

They also sell pies that I want to try: egg pie, halo halo pie, Buko (coconut) pie.
author: Alexa R.

description:
After going to an event at August Hall , we were starving and were deliberating where to go eat. I pulled up yelp and luckily found this place! Filipino food at 2 am ?? I couldn't believe it . Hells yes.

Knowing me I don't eat at too many Filipino establishments since I'm always disappointed. It's never as good or doesn't come close as moms / grandmas food. However, I'd have to differ when I finally got a taste at Tselogs. It was like having home cooked Filipino food back at Moms.

Bangsilog: Baby milkfish marinated in vinegar, pepper and salt. Came with garlic fried rice & an over easy egg. *drools* it was so good . The fish was cooked to a nice crisp and it was salty and tangy when dipped into the sauce. ( You have to ask them for it) The sauce had vinegar , garlic , and chilies. Make sure you ask for the sauce on the side to get the " full experience ". 5/5

Lechon kawali: Deep fried pork belly with "San Thomas sauce ". It was good but could've been a little crunchier. This dish also comes with garlic rice & an egg . 4/5

Overall , if you're looking for a satisfying meal after hitting the clubs, Tselogs is conveniently open until 3 am Fridays and Saturday's!Thanks Tselogs for the great food , chill music & awesome service ! All of the workers were super friendly and happy to help . I will be back again to try the other dishes.
author: Elle F.

description:
***TLDR: Delicious comfort food at an affordable price point. Try the pork belly and shredded chicken.***

Ordered the Lechon Kawali Silog (crispy pork belly) and the Sisigsilog (Shredded seasoned chicken). Both were delicious. The portions are a little on the smaller side, but most people should leave feeling just the right amount of full. 

The inside of the store is definitely on the smaller side and there may be a bit of a wait. Would recommend getting take out and getting home quick to eat it while it's still warm.
author: Sterling C.

description:
First time eating Filipino food and I love this small joint! It's narrow here; there's 7 seats by the cook and another 5 seats facing the wall I believe. The window by the front is for ordering to-go or pick up. 

Service is good even though they forgot one of the order. Very apologetic. 

Got the sisigsilog- sizzling chicken (shredded). Very flavorful and I love the lemon wedge that comes with it .. smell so good and adds more flavor. Not overly greasy either. 

Tocilog - cured sweet pork... ahmazingggg! I thought it will be like a jerky type texture but the pork actually is so tender and falls apart. Tasted so good but a bit oily. 

The meat plates comes with garlic rice and a fried egg. I definitely recommend getting a combo if you are interested in trying different meats. 

Definitely recommend this spot. Street parking was plenty on a Thursday night around 9:30p!
author: Oanh P.

description:
We were down the street at a bar for happy hour. Although the drinks were good, I was dissatisfied with the food. So I made the short trek to this tiny filipino resto and I'm so glad I did. 

There was no wait when we walked in, but the line was a dozen deep about 10 minutes later. The menu lists the usual suspects  (pancit, lumpia, sweet spaghetti, etc.). I'm a huge fan of longanisa (filipino sausage) so that's what I ordered. The plate consisted of three sausages, garlic rice, and some cucumbers on the side. The plate was perfect for a late dinner. My dinner mates got the chicken sisig which they liked too. This is a good place to get your filipino fix.
author: Mel L.

description:
Came here when I was fatigued and hungry from a day of exploring San Francisco. Almost missed the place (the entrance is quite small), but I was able to spot the line waiting outside of the venue. Despite the line, the wait was relatively short for a party of two (around 15 minutes). There's limited seating, and the place is styled like a very traditional sushi bar (so I do not recommend coming here in big parties). 

We started off with the lumpia Shanghai ($6), and the appetizer itself was pretty fulfilling. Though the portion was big, the contents inside the lumpia weren't the most flavorful and juicy I've tried, but nevertheless still a great filler while waiting for your main dishes. 

I ordered the combination with bangsilog and tocilog ($13). The portion was very appropriately big. The fish was well-fried, and the pork was sweet and tender. The rice was very flavorful, and it blended well with the garlic sprinkled on top. 

We got the ube macapuno pie after the meal ($4.50). The ube was very creamy and soft, and the pie crust was filling and not too hard. We originally ordered the halo-halo, but we changed our minds at the last second; the waiter was nice enough to change the order for us. 

Definitely a recommend for anyone looking for filling, authentic Filipino food!
author: Jim X.

description:
Good traditional Filipino food, affordable prices, very fast at cooking, and nice staff.
There were lots of Filipino customers inside, which is always a good sign.
author: Federico P.

description:
Great place to grab a quick meal! The menu has a good range of meals, with the main dish being - as the name suggests - Filipino silog. 

The restaurant itself is clean and interior fits it nicely. The wall seating is a little small, but it would've been hard to fit more tables in. 

I say at the bar and ordered Sisigsilog. A very flavourful chopped chicken dish, that comes with a side of garlic rice and a sunny side up egg. The food came very quickly after I ordered it; it was filling, tasty, and all I really hoped for. Would come here again.
author: Mati K.

description:
This small little dainty place in the Tenderloin district of San Francisco, never fails to fulfill my Filipino cravings. My roomie and I passed by for take-out on our way home from SFO. Whenever we go to the city, I make it a point to stop by. That's how good they are!

 The place was packed! Of course, that could also be due to it being such a tiny spot that only probably sits about 10 people. There was a guy taking names outside and two of the chefs were prepping the plates inside. 

Having two other locations I have personally tried, this location is the best by far. Not only do you get great food in decent proportions for a good price, but you get a chance to see the chefs in cooking action. The place is clean, the ingredients fresh and your meal prepared to order. I call this place a bit of home, it's a Filipino culinary mecca that speaks close to the heart. This resto is a hidden gem!

Nothing beats their chicken sisig silog which is seasoned chicken pieces in a mouth watering sauce served on a sizzling hot plate with garlic fried rice, cucumber, tomato, and a fried egg. Most definitely not the healthiest but the most delicious. This is my favorite filipino food place whenever I go to SFO. I will be back, no doubt about it!
author: Rowena V.

description:
I'm going to be honest - when my friends brought up this place, I wasn't feeling it. Rice, meat, and an egg is not the type of food I was craving at 1 am but I'm always willing to try new places and I'm glad I wasn't dramatic about it.

Seating wise there's enough room for like 12 people max, so either be ready for a wait or get take out.

It's a shack type of place and they're really quick with service and food so people get in and out fast as long as they don't sit and gossip about their day.

Neighborhood wise it is close to Tenderloin so consider that when street parking!

Food: I had the noodles with chicken and they were amazing with the sauce that comes with the egg rolls and with some lemon juice. I wish you could get them with pork!

There was also a deep fried porkbelly dish not on the menu but it was easily one of the tastiest porkbellies I've had. I would definitely recommend that over the noodles.

The chopped chicken was also great! It's crispier than you'd think and the ginger adds a great taste to it.

I also recommend the 12 piece eggrolls for $7 on the back page. They're pretty small but super delicious as an appetizer until food comes out.

I don't think I'd bring it up as a place to go to my friends because I'm not a HUUUGE fan of the menu, but I wouldn't be disappointed going again if everyone else in my group wanted to
author: Elin M.

description:
I thought the food here was only okay. I got a combo plate with the sweet pork belly and the milk fish. We also had some lumpias to share. 

Food came out pretty fast but everything is already prepared ahead of time so I wouldn't have expected  any longer. 

I really liked the milk fish, wished I just got a rice plate with just that. The sweet pork belly was not good IMO, I didn't care for it. Lumpias were really good, nice and crispy. 

I sat next to the speaker so it was very unpleasant as the music was blasting in my ear...
author: Kelly L.

description:
If you are in the Tenderloin and wish to savor Silog options, this Tselogs location is a good choice. Essentially a portmanteau form of two words: Sinangag (Garlic Fried Rice) and Itlog (Egg), the Filipino breakfast staple comprises of fried rice, cured meat and egg. A combination that make for comfort food at its morning best (or at 2AM post a night of imbibing). 

Depending on the cured meat served in combination with the Fried Rice and Egg, Silog variants go by various acronyms. Example: Tapsilog (has Tapa: cured beef or pork that is traditionally sun-dried but cured in the refrigerator nowadays), Tocilog (has Tocino - typically grilled cured pork belly), Longsilog (has Longganisa - Filipino sausage), Cornbisilog (has corned beef), Spamsilog (has Spam), Hotsilog (has you guessed it, Hot Dog!).

While the menu is silog-centric, they also have other specials like Lumpiang Shanghai (Spring Rolls) and noodle dishes including Pancit Bihon (stir-fried rice noodles), Palabok (noodles layered with sauce and various garnishes) and Chicken/Beef Mami (Egg Noodle Soup).

We ordered the Chicken Sisigsilog and found it to be exceptional. Space is limited so expect a few minutes of wait time outside if the place is packed. We hope to be back again the next time we are in the area.
author: Vinayak B.

description:
Yeah, yeah - the seating is limited to 12, the space is basically an oversized closet, you may have to wait an extended time and perhaps leave and return to wait some more at a different time of day or a different day altogether.

It is all worth it. This is the Sisigsilog center of SFO.

Sit facing the kitchen.  Watch the chefs cook in front of your eyes in their epic ballet.  Inhale the spices from the hot pans gusting up in an exotic east Asian aromatic mouthwatering mélange cloud. Enjoy the food itself, a symphonic explosion of flavors.

I'd ordered two dishes for myself and made recommendations to those seated at each side of my party to do the same.  They opted to also  double up.  We all ate every last bit and ordered dessert.  

If you have never had Filipino food, come on down to Tselogs - an eye opener and a mouth waterer.  

My heart to Mr. W for the anniversary trip back to the town where it all began.
author: Maria W.

description:
This meal was probably the best meal I've had in San Francisco.

Which says a lot considering I ate at a few restaurants during my short time here. 

We were staying at a hotel about a block or 2 away from this place and since it was raining we decided on this spot. 

The place would be hard to miss since it's a hole in a wall so make sure to be on the lookout! 

When we got there, we were the only ones there so we were able to choose our seats towards the back of the restaurant. 

The staff was super friendly and helpful when giving us recommendations! We decided to get the sizzsing, lechon and meatloaf. Each of these dishes came with a bowl of garlic rice as well as a fried runny egg! The sizzsing was my favorite followed by the lechon and lastly the meatloaf. However they were all a close tie with each other. 

I was really surprised by how authentic and delicious the Filipino food was from this little joint. It's definitely one of the better Filipino food I've had. I've had plenty of Filipino food back in New York City but the simplicity and comfort feeling of Tselogs dishes really tops the cake!

If I'm ever back in San Francisco, I'm definitely hitting up Tselogs again!
author: Belle L.

description:
Tselogs is now considered a local chain of authentic Filipin@ restaurants.  However, this location is less then desirable unless you happen to be from the Union Square / Tenderknob area or coming in from a night of partying. 

The reason being is that this location is relatively smaller than almost all other locations in Daly City.  The price may be a little different considering the location and while portions have gotten smaller over the years, the portions here are a little more slight.  The restaurant seems to have been converted from a sushi restaurant which is necessarily conducive to Filipin@ food. If you really want to experience this restaurant, this wouldn't be the best location
author: Joel Christian A.

description: Great hole-in-the-wall place to have filipino food. I got the chicken dish with rice, and it was delicious, the best chicken I've eaten in a long time. And the garlic rice... so simple but very tasty.
author: Santiago R.

description:
Ok.  Wow.  I'm still Oooing & Aaaaing to myself when I think about my meal at Tselogs.  I never thought I would be impressed by Filipino food.  I'm Filipino, I grew up eating Filipino food all my life, & for the most part the cooking is simple, straightforward, & "homey" for the lack of a better word.  Welp.. I was wrong.

I initially planned to get ramen that night, but once I got to the ramen place and saw the line was almost 1/2 a block long, plan B kicked in 'cause ain't nobody got time for that!  Reee-diculous.

I got to Tselogs and the first thing I noticed was that it was really SMALL.  You have your tables to the left and your cooking/prepping space in direct view on the right.  There's about 12 seats in the restaurant so definitely be prepared to get cozy with your neighbors!  I chose to sit on the right, so I could watch the meals being prepared and because I like to have more table space when I'm eating.

The cashier/busser/server, all-around awesome guy explained the menu to me and he could probably tell I couldn't decide what to get because he quickly followed-up with explaining the "combo" where I could pick TWO items.  I settled on the tapsilog & sisigsilog combo.

Each dish is usually paired with garlic fried rice with egg on top & some veggies.  The tapsilog - a sweet braised beef - was very tasty, but the real winner here was the sisigsilog.  It came out sizzling hot on a cast iron skillet with a lemon on top.  I took one bite & wow... Mind blown! The lemon was just the perfect touch.  The server recommended putting the itlog (egg) on top of the chicken, mixing it around the skillet, & then finishing it off with the lemon juice.  Freakin' amazing.  Why have I never had this dish?!?  So crazy.  I think the one thing they could improve on is their garlic fried rice.  It's good, but could be elevated SO much more. 

Overall though, the service was quick (it really needs to be in a restaurant this small to turn tables faster).  The server was very friendly and although he was busy, he still engaged me in some small talk which I appreciate.  

I'm a fan Tselogs! I'll be back next time I'm in SF!
author: Maria P.

description: Good food! Super Small place but it's cute!! Come check them out!! Great simple everyday Filipino food that you will definitely not get sick of !!
author: Margaret L.

description:
Delicious place!

The food has really great flavor here! I've been twice and both dishes I got were great. I prefer the noodle dish instead but can never go wrong with soup either. The first dish I got the first time was the palabok which was so yummy! I love glass noodles in general but their sauce and topping made it a dish I'd order again. The second time I went I got the bihon which had a good broth.

Both times I went, my friends got the chicken sisig.
It had a great aroma with garlic and had a ton of flavor packed in that little skillet. Portion wise you made be surprised so you may want a side dish with it.

Customer service is also very friendly and attentive.

Beware that it is a small place. It's more of a get it to go spot if you have more than 2 people eating. Most people call in orders or just wait by the door for food and don't even try to eat her if they see 4 people already sitting down.
author: Laura Y.

description:
The BEST Filipino restaurant in San Francisco !!! 
Love this place because the food is very authentic and not trying hard. 
FOOD: 
Got shanghai, longsilog, tapasilog, sisig plate with lechon kawali; ALL is very delicious but the garlic rice is the best! I love there garlic rice because you can tell they use fresh garlic and they just don't use garlic powder.  
FYI: lechon kawali is not on the menu just ask them if they have it and if they do they can definitely do it for you.
Service is really great, very friendly. 
Price is affordable and reasonable. 
Also, the good thing about this restaurant they open till 3am. So, after drinking or if you want midnight snack go here!
Definitely I would go back here and recommend this  restaurant.
author: Tellie N.

description:
This place is awesome!!! 

Ambience: A+ this place isn't very big, but they make it work. Music is totally on point. The workers here sing and everyone is generally in a fantastic mood. 

Food: porridge with chicken. Super delicious and cozy. Sausage with garlic rice is amazing. I'm not the biggest fan of the sausage because it is on the sweeter side, but man that garlic rice is good. The chefs kept giving us random pickled veggies and sauces to eat. They're so fun and nice. Definitely want to come back and try other dishes. I was eyeballing everyone else's food. Lumpia is good. Order this to start! We also got pie because were fat. It wasn't too sweet which is what I like best.
author: Dianna C.

description:
Yeesh! Was skeptical about eating Filipino food at midnight since I just flew in and wanted something that really hit the spot, but am I glad that I did come here!

The neighborhood is pretty sketchy, was told that it's known as the "tenderloin". Lots of homeless and druggies around, but just don't make eye contact and keep on moving. Was surprised since this was my first time in SF and I had no idea what to expect.

The place closes at midnight on a weekday and I came in around 11:40pm. The guy recommended the Chicken Tselogs, and while I thought I was feeling some sort of beef or fatty meat, holy chicken this was good! 

The chicken was seasoned very very well, and had some sort of liquid/cream cooked into it. It also comes with garlic rice (super tasty), a slice of cucumber and lemon.

Damn, I will be looking out for more filipino food in the future and I hope that it's as good as this place! $15 CC minimum.
author: Daniel Z.

description:
Awesome hole-in-the-wall Filipino diner. I had no idea what to order, but the staff was very accommodating with giving great recommendations.  This place serves awesome, quick comfort food in a casual atmosphere. They were playing some sweet throwback tunes as well. Gotta love some classic 2000s Akon.

The pareselog beef was sweet and had a nice soy sauce + star anise flavor. I would recommend!
author: Steven H.

description:
I'm a tough critic when it comes to Filipino food, reason why? I am a Filipino American who grew up with Filipino food and everyone knows that Mom's cooking was always the best and not comparable to others. I was skeptic about the suggestion but it was the closest eatery around. 

Upon walking in I saw a window you can order from? Kinda neat if you want it to go  or if there is no room inside. When I arrived the canteen was packed. A small whole in the wall located in the Tenderloin area. Luckily 2 people left and there was space front and center of the chefs.

Reading through the menu, I see Tocino which is bacon-pork belly formed in cubes   and marinated in wine, sugar, anatto, and water. Fried and crispy on ends. I haven't ate in a while so yes I'll take that. Typically served with garlic fried rice and a over easy egg. My homies ordered the Chicken Sisig- boiling, grilling chicken, chopped onions, and chili pepppers. It is considered a Filipino delicacy.

Wait time was 20mins, plenty of time to see what's for dessert? I have to say when our meals came out, I was uber happy. Just like how I cook it at home, the Tocino it is; but the Sisig was delicious. Flavorful and mouthwatering.

What I was bumb'd out about was they ran out of Buko pie! Oh wells, I'll have to come back.
author: Kathy V.

description:
Tselogs is possibly one of my favorite restaurants to go to. This one located in the tenderloin, serves only about 15-20 people at a time because just like SF, there's no space at all. Due to the limited space, be ready to wait. Fortunately, the staff does a good job of managing seats so you'll be seated within 15-20 minutes depending on party size. 

Eats: sisigsilog combo with lechon kawali 10/10 $16
-the lechon (roasted pork belly) is an off the menu item FYI. When served came with about 8-10 pieces. Each piece was 70% fat to 30% meat but that is exactly what you look for in a serving of lechon. Each bite was succulent and rich in delicious grease. What did somewhat lack was the crunch factor of the skin. It had more of a gelatinous texture to it. 

-sisig
The sisig differs here than anywhere that I've had it as this is not traditional sisig. Traditional sisig usually consists of pork cheek, pork brains, pork ear and other fun parts of the pig. I guess to make it more appealing to the American public, they opted to use chicken instead. Fortunately the tselogs take on sisig is as delicious and possibly even better than most sisig dishes out there. When served it comes out on a sizzling stone skillet. The aroma that the sisig gives always makes me salivate. Each bite is salty and acidic. The blend of lemon, vinegar and soy sauce are flavors prominent within the sisig. What is somewhat missing in the tselogs version of the sisig is the spice of ginger and Chiles. I do love the tselogs version of the sisig as it gives the restaurant it's own flare to it and it appeals to both sisig lovers and those who have never tried sisig before. 

What I love about tselogs is the consistency in all their dishes. Whether it's this location or the one in Daly City, the food is consistently delicious from when it first reaches my table to when I knock out in my car from having a food coma. When enjoying any sorts of food, you want to have consistent flavors and here at Tselogs they serve that up and then some.
author: James L.

description:
I walked by this restaurant late one night, and it felt like I was passing an intimate dinner in someone's home. And the smell was HEAVENLY. I forgot the location of the restaurant, but my manfriend felt like Pilipino food one night. A quick Google Search brought me back. No hesitation- were going to Tselogs.

AMBIANCE gives me such down home vibes. The woman greeting us had such a loving personality, it felt like grandma's. The space is small and quaint: there are only two rows of seats, which I imagine could make for quite a line during busy hours. We came around 9:30pm, so we were lucky to score two seats facing the kitchen where everything was prepared in front of us. To our left, a stereo played a balance of slow and energetic Pilipino music. 

ORDERED lumpia Shanghai, tapsilog with garlic rice, buko pie, and calamansi juice.

FOOD was delicious! The lumpia Shanghai (a must have!) had a crisp crunch, and I felt lucky to have my first taste of tapsilog and buko pie here.

RATING is a hearty five. Good prices, a home-style feel, and amazing food makes for a solid evening/late night spot near Union Square.
author: Nicholas G.

description:
Amazing! We loved the food here so much. We got it to go because the space is pretty small and it was full, but our hotel was close by. We ordered he tapsilog (beef) and the best seller, sisig silog (chicken). Incredible food, really affordable, and they had it ready within about 15 min. 

The rice and eggs are perfectly done with each dish, too. 

Note that they don't serve any alcohol here, so not a great place to sit and drink.
author: Dave S.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place for awhile now and decided to come here for my birthday weekend breakfast.   I ordered a combo tocino and tapa silog.  Both had a very 'stew like' texture, tasted like it was cooked in a slow cooker- i'm sorry but tocino and tapa are not supposed to taste like stew.  I usually will devour filipino breakfast silogs but I couldn't finish half of my plate because the meats just tasted weird.  The lumpia was standard and the BF had the spaghetti and he said that was fine too.  I've had alot of filipino food in my life and that was just the weirdest filipino meals I've had.  

Also, we saw them nuke a corn pie in the microwave.

We both walked out of Tselogs underwhelmed.
author: Clarissa P.

description:
Delish!!  We were in search of some Filipino food here in San Francisco during our visit and Tselogs did not disappoint!

It is small.  Very.  However the service is quick and the food is delicious!  You sit at a little bar and watch your food (and everyone else) being made.  Its hard to stick with your order because everything looks sooooo good!!  The portions are great for the value and piping hot, right off the stove!

I would come here again...and again!  Get the Pancit Bichon and Lumpia!  Both are wonderful and made fresh!
author: Tasjuaii M.

description:
If your  looking for delicious and affordable Filipino food, THIS IS YOUR PLACE. 

Okay, so we walk in and fell in love with the small quaint familial feel of the place. While they were cooking, I got lost in all the aromas; which made me want to order and eat everything on the menu. 

Service time: swift. Quality of food: can't beat it. Look, I don't know how else to say this, but this is the real San Francisco treat. It's the golden gate of Filipino food in the area. It is where you should be for dinner tonight. 

We had the lumpia and pancit. I mean, what else would you eat that's symbolic Filipino food?!? Well, it was amazing! The portions were perfect and atop of it all, the gentlemen who ran the establishment were the kindest. 

Thanks for a great experience!
author: Emiel B.

description:
Was so glad that this place was a block away from our hotel - truly a hole in the wall! 

Boyfriend and I ordered lumpia to share, chicken sisig, lechon kawali, and the palabok. Everything was made-to-order and delicious! I had never had palabok before and was glad I tried something new. Lumpia was freshly fried and perfectly crunchy.
author: Rachel Z.

description: Awesome food with late closing over the weekends! Been here atleast 50 times and other then the occasionally under cooked rice (like twice really) it's the best!
author: James O.

description:
Awesome late night spot. I always go for the Sisig Silog on the sizzling hot plate, but my friends have gotten basically everything on the menu and nothing has disappointed.

Be prepared to wait though if you're coming in during any peak hours(anytime after everything else closes) there are only about 10-15 seats in the entire restaurant, so be mindful of that as well!
author: Andrew T.

description:
New to SF, we found this place thanks to the Yelp community. Filipino food was something we really wanted to try, and we asked our server for recommendations. We got the chicken siselig and dry noodles (with meat and seafood) and both of these dishes were delicious. This place not only has the yummiest or food, but the team there keeps the energy high with smiles and some fun upbeat music. We enjoyed each moment of our time spent here. If you're in the area, definitely go. 
PS- it's a really small place so consider that before you make the trip. It's a quick meal.
author: Neha D.

description:
If you're craving Filipino food, come here! 
The dishes are authentic, made with fresh ingredients, and taste amazing!

On a side note, we ordered the Shanghai lumpia and halfway through our meal, staff gave us an extra one cuz they said we should've gotten one more. Who's impressed? THIS GIRL!
author: Mandi W.

description:
I can't believe I didn't know this place existed until just recently! As a Filipino food fanatic, I used to assume that I can only find the authentic, legit restaurants in Daly City.  While I have some personal favs there, I'm now obsessed with Tselogs since it's in SF and more easily accessible for me.

The wait can be long, so I suggest coming during off hours (or maybe just Postmates it).  Once you're in, the hardest part is choosing what to order. I always want to eat everything! 

Out of all of the things I've tried thus far, the Chicken Sisig is by far my favorite. It comes out sizzling hot (literally). Drizzle over with some fresh lemon juice, add rice, and it's a hot bite of heaven in your mouth!

Tip: If you're a lechon lover like me, know that this plate does exist! It's just not on their menu. I also like this a lot because it's rich but not 99.9% fat like other places. You still get your fix of actual meat, which is nice!

I'm drooling as I write this, and will need my fix of Tselogs soon!
author: Judy C.

description: Good food especially for the inebriated crowd. It's hard to spot due to the small sign and overall small space. Everything served with rice and an egg. I suggest the sisig, tocilog, and fried chicken. Spot can definitely get packed fast so try to takeout if you can
author: Anthony C.

description:
If you're looking for some Filipino comfort food - this is the place. 

Cozy spot. Came in on Friday afternoon. No wait. Quickly seated and greeted by the friendly staff. Ordered the lumpia to share, sisigsilog for me, and lechon kawali for my boyfriend. Everything was so good! Had been missing my parents' home cooking, so this definitely fulfilled my craving. 

I've got to try more things off the menu, so I'll be back!
author: Liyanne E.

description:
The food can take about 10-15 mins as they state on the menu but holy shit the food is so good.

The restaurant itself is tiny - think hole in the wall Japanese ramen bar setting - but the staff is super entertaining the watch. As my bf and I inhaled our food, they were just doing their tasks and singing along to the music.

We ordered the sisigsilog, combo with lechon and sisigsilog, and halo halo pie (with ice cream on top).

Everything was perfectly portioned and tasted so amazing. We'll definitely be back if we're in the area again.
author: Tina T.

description:
Loved the staff and great food. Their sisig is very different from any I've had as it was made with actual chicken meat on sizzling plate, which crisped up some of the pieces! I also got a side of the broth because I was craving something hot and it was literally a bowl of chicken broth hahaha JUST LIKE HOME! 

The actual space is nice, designed like a ramen bar where it's a bar facing the kitchen. Seating is very limited but everyone was pretty friendly so no complaints here today!
author: May C.

description: I don't know Filipino food that well but if all of their comfort food tastes like this then it's now officially my favorite comfort food of all time! The chicken sisig is amazing but their beef porridge is out of this world. And to top it off it's the pricing is very reasonable, at least by SF standards. Just thinking of the food again makes my mouth water.
author: Carl W.

description:
A group of us stumbled upon Tselogs a few weeks ago after an evening out, and I think we all agree that this was a great end to this fun night. None of us had ever heard of Tselogs, and the only reason we went was because it was across the street from Bourbon and Branch, where we decided we needed some late-night eats. 

We must have arrived around 1am, and there was a bit of a wait. There were four of us, but we probably got seated within 15 minutes. I do not remember exactly what we ordered, as I kind of went along with the group and didn't keep track of the name of the dishes, but I remember the amazing flavors. Tselogs is an absolute must if you're craving good Filipino food.
author: Melissa R.

description:
I love Tselongs. Their food is soo good. I usually just order over the phone and pick it up. 

Taking a star off because compared to other restaurants, their food portions are pretty tiny. 

If your looking for total Asian comfort food, this is the place to check out.
author: Shanzay H.

description:
Very disappointed. Been wanting to try this place. Came Friday late around 11:30pm. Ordered chicken sisig and palabok. The wait seemed a bit long for to-go and considering most of the patrons inside we're finishing up. So basically they only had our order to cook.

Palabok was just ok. My sisigsilog was bad. Rice was soooo hard, not very garlicky and chicken was dry, hard and just slathered in sauce. I couldn't eat my food. It was just too hard. 

Sad... based on the reviews I was expecting a lot more but won't be going back.

Also didn't like how every other worker came out and was smoking cigarettes right in front of the shop.

They get 2 stars because the palabok was ok.
author: M L.

description:
It was my first time going to SF location. I am a Tselogs lover because of their Filipino cuisine. I always go to the Daly city location with my family and friends. 

Me and my cousin went tonight, 4/20/18, after the Marian Hill concert at Warfield. Tselogs was about 10 mins walk from Warfield and its open late on a Friday. Tselogs in SF is very small in size. You can only sit few people inside and the rest will have to wait for about 15-20 mins depending if its a pack night. You can order to-go if you rather not wait. Parking will be difficult since its in SF. 

I ordered a combo of tapa and lechon kawali while my cousin ordered a combo chicken sisig and lechon kawali. While waiting for our order, me and my cousin were jamming to the OPM playing in the background. Although a small place, the place was really chill. 

Our orders arrived in about 10 mins. Everything was set and we were eating already however, I noticed that they forgot to put an egg on my plate. I don't really mind it without the egg but it feels incomplete without it since its a silog. I asked the server for the egg and they apologized to me while giving me my egg I apologized as well but the server told me that it was their mistake so they apologized again.

Tselogs is a really good place to go if you're craving for silogs. I always recommend this place to other people because its worth the wait.
author: Kathleen L.

description:
Came here a few days ago  with friends and we were a total of 10. This place is small so I don't really recommend for big groups. It's all bar seating. They cook the food infront of you once you finish ordering. After your meal, you will smell like filipino food which I don't mind if I'm coming home right after. 

The food was okay. I liked the tocino & lechon kawali. The longanisa and the sisig wasn't bad. The fried bangus didn't satisfy me & I can't put my fingers as to why. The garlic rice was a little hard and I didn't really taste the garlic.. 

I think I expected too much because of all the good reviews; this place maybe a little overhyped. The prices are fine but I've been to places that gave more food for the price I paid. The service was pretty good though. 

Don't get me wrong, I liked the food. I just expected too much I guess.
author: Charlyn P.

description:
Filipino comfort food...

This location is in San Francisco in the not-so-great neighborhood of the Tenderloin District. The place is very tiny. As soon as you step inside you're literally in the heart of everything - the take-out counter, the dining area, the kitchen and just a few steps, the restroom.  One side is a small counter and we were literally facing the kitchen where you see the cooks/staff take food out of the fridge, cook and prepare your meal. I don't remember how many people this side sits... six, maybe eight?  The wooden chairs have no backs and the seats aren't wide so, um, just take caution and take note if dining in. Behind us, well, I couldn't tell if this is another place to sit and eat because the long counter is even smaller but it may fit their tiny plates. No one sat on this side while we were there so I'm not sure. There were bar chairs.
 
We were given a menu. The silog choices were simple and served with garlic fried rice and one egg.  Everything looks so yummy! I was also eyeing other specials they have including palabok, arroz caldo and pancit bihon among others. And, yes, this tiny eatery also serves homemade desserts! I can't remember the choices but the halo-halo pie caught my eye. This was my first time here and it took me a while to decide but finally went with tocilog (tocino meat) while hubby ordered his favorite, longsilog (longanisa). The plates the dishes were served on were small and the serving size seemed fit for a child but to my surprise my meal was filling and was just the right serving for me. It was tasty and delicious. The gals working there were nice... they didn't interact much with the patrons except to take your order and serve your food.  Oh well...
 
This restaurant is really the definition of a 'hole in the wall'.  Everything may be small but the flavorful meals packs on a big punch. Parking, as it is everywhere else in San Francisco, is always challenging. We were lucky to find one just right outside the eatery. Good luck! LoL!

Review #0802
author: May A.

description:
It took a couple of walks down Jones to actually find this place - it's a little unassuming - but glad we persevered. It's a tiny little hole in the wall with literally just a couple of counters (one of which faces directly into the kitchen). If you're looking for a fine dining table service, it isn't the place for you - however the service here is quick, friendly and casual. 
We walked straight in without a wait and sat right down at the counter. One of the chefs immediately handed over a couple of menus and some water - and though I knew what I wanted, he was very happy to offer his recommendation to my dad - on and off menu. His recommendation was the spiced beef or the off-menu pork belly. 
I went for the arroz caldo and sisigsilog - both of which were great. The arroz was my favourite - if I'd chosen again I would have ordered a large arroz, added an egg and stuck to that. 
We ordered an egg pie for dessert - and this is the only reason it doesn't get a 5*. It was tasty, however didn't taste the freshest - the pastry itself was a little stale tasting - I guess it was from yesterday. I still enjoyed it however. 
I settled the bill, and a couple minutes later the chef informed me he'd accidentally overcharged me. I hadn't noticed, so it was really great that they were so honest. 
Overall a great option if you're in the area. Quick, simple, tasty and fuss-free. The takeout looks pretty good too!
author: Poppy C.

description: Place is BOMB! Right around the corner from my hotel and is a must try...had sigsig chicken, spaghetti, lechon kowali, hot dog and lumpia..Not better than aunty's but pretty up to par!
author: Roger S.

description: Fried bangus silog hit the spot! The baby bangus fish is not only cute but the perfect portion for lunch. Don't forget to dip the crispy fish in vinegar to get the full effect of bangsilog! I like the size of this spot -- quaint and quick. Just don't bring a big group and expect to sit comfortably.
author: Michelle M.

description:
There are times when I tend to equate food with the same feelings as love. With that being said, Tselogs would be the guy I have always wanted to date, but wasn't quite 100% sure about. Because he's rough around the edges, but once you've gotten a chance to date him once and get to know him, you think about him all the time. And want to date him again and again...no matter what the obstacles are. 

Yes, it's that good. When I'm likening food to love, you know I'm hooked! 

I had just sang & danced my ass off at the Duran Duran concert in SF. It was close to midnight & I was hungry (like the wolf, haha. Sorry, couldn't resist!). What was still open? I checked my handy Yelp bookmarks & decided this would be my chance to try this place! I've read about it, as well as told that it was THE bizznomb by friend & fellow Yelper Lex. So I told my two favorite guys I was with, "Come with me, let's try this place!" We luckily found parking in this bustling area about two blocks away on a busy Saturday night. 

Here are all the Yesses. Yes, it's a small hole-in-the-wall spot. Yes, it's hard to find parking, though we lucked out (meant to be!). Yes, it's not in the greatest area, in the Tenderloin (though I wasn't in danger or scared, you just have to be alert). But even after all this, I say Yes, yes, YES, absolutely you must GO! Don't think about it, debate it, or doubt it. JUST GO, BECAUSE IT'S THAT GOOD! 

GOOD TO KNOW - There is a To-Go window! So you can call ahead & happily take your order with you. But we chose to dine there because there was no wait. But after a few minutes, there was a line out the door seven people deep!

Upon walking in, if I had to guess, I would say about a dozen people fit in there. Barstool sitting against counters. Fully open kitchen diner-style. CLEAN, FRIENDLY, PERSONABLE, & DOWN-HOME FILIPINO COOKING! Just glancing at the menu made me happy. See pic for menu.

A shout out to PATRICK, our server and MATT, our cook, who took care of us this night. 

** IT'S ALL ABOUT THE SIZZLING CHICKEN SISIG HERE! $9.99. This is what my brother ordered & I wanted to steal it because, after all, I am the older sister! He was generous & gave me some bites. :) Admittedly, I have never had sisig in my life & if I did, I just don't remember. (I know, I know, don't judge.) BUT THIS CHICKEN SISIG IS EVERYTHING! Marinated chicken grilled & served sizzling In a pan, with other ingredients on a separate plate for mixing - the garlic fried rice & egg. YOU MUST ORDER THIS. TRUST ME! I'm definitely getting this next time, and even one to-go! The flavors are undeniable the grilled, marinated chicken goodness is still haunting me & luring me back. All this FORKALICIOUS 5-STAR GOODNESS for only $9.99.

** TAPSILOG (beef tapa) $9.99, was my choice, complete w/ garlic rice & fried egg. Very good & I do recommend! I enjoyed every bite of this and I would get this again. Though the chicken sisig is still the better-looking boyfriend. ;) 

** TOCILOG, marinated pork, the hubster's choice, was very good. He loved it so much, I looked over & it had already disappeared! Haha! $8.99.

At this price range for Filipino food in SF, I really don't think it gets better than this. So go, go, and free yourself to enjoy this goodness and fall in love like I did. 

I think it's time for another date with Tselogs soon...
author: Cristina A.

description:
...yikes. How do you whiff so badly on Filipino food???

And I am by no means comparing this to the food from the islands, but even like street truck lumpia is better than this (and about $10 cheaper per dish).

I ordered take-out sisig and tocilog and both were straight up bland (honestly, I thought it would take serious effort to make sisig, the greatest pork-biproduct dish on God's green earth, "bland", but there you go).

What's worse, tiny AF portions?

4.5 stars? 

I just don't get it. This is a bad trip... unless you like bland food... can't IMAGINE anyone in the town, especially new arrivals, who like THAT... *sigh*...

BRB. Need to head to Daly City. ;-)
author: Mike V.

description:
Fried Chicken,Garlic Rice w/ Egg soft over easy
added side of Lumpia (smaller thin version)
Good Service: 4/5 Stars
Lumpia's - Where is the Meat Filing 1/5 
Garlic Rice - Moist/Lots of Garlic flavor 4/5
Egg Over Soft Easy 5/5 -Perfect 
Fried Chicken, No seasoning at All.
Over Fried Chicken - Dry Chicken 
Had Better at Kentucky Fried Chicken. Which
is lot Cheaper.

Ugh...Not Worth the $ 16:85
author: Food Sage W.

description:
I spotted Tselogs in one of runs to Shalimar (which is just a couple of spots away) so decided to give it a try. After a couple of initial failed attempts around the time when they had just opened, I finally managed to try them for dinner a couple of days ago. 

Tselogs is a very small place with a row of 10-12 counter seats to your right, so even with a small number of people inside it looks very crowded. Earlier you had to go in and place your to-go orders. This made the place even more full with people hanging around the entrance for their orders. Now they have opened up a small window outside where you can place and pickup to-go orders making the process a lot smoother.

Menu is your standard protein + silog (fried egg and rice). I decided to get the Chicken Sisig Silog ($9.99) to-go. If I remember correctly I could pay by card and the order was ready in 10-12 minutes so pretty smooth.

I got a decent sized container with all correct components, fried egg, garlic rice and chicken sisig. Unfortunately everything was subpar. The fried egg was so overdone that the outer ring was almost burnt. The garlic rice was hard and over steamed. The chicken sisig was overly greasy and was topped with crispy bacon bits. The crispy bacon bits were really hard which made the chicken sisig crunchy. I didn't like this at all.

Price wise they were a little less when compared to Senor Sisig food truck but the quality of the food was not even close. The only thing that it has got going for itself is that it is open real late on the weekends, which gets me to stop by once in a while.
author: Ahmad J.

description:
Lunch review. Filipino.

Lumpia shanghai - 3
Longanisa - 4
Tocilig - 5
Garlic rice - 3

Overall, probably "as good as it gets" for Filipino actually in the city.
author: Mark O.

description:
Location/accessibility: 3/5
No parking! Also in the Tenderloin district, so incredibly busy. 
 
Atmosphere/service: N/A
Ordered for takeout! Definitely recommend if you don't want to look for parking--you can just have someone jump out and pick up the food. 

Food: 5/5
Ordered the Sisigsilog (Chicken sisig) and Tocilog (Sweet Marinated Pork). The sisigsilog is a definitely must try and will get it again. The Tocilog was good, too, but willing to give it up to try other stuff on the menu. Both come with garlic rice and an egg. Everything was SOOOOO good. 

Pricing: 5/5
Dinner for 2 in SF for under $25 (including tax!) is great! Super filling too!
author: Michelle N.

description:
This is a tiny hole-in-the-wall spot for great Filipino food! I love that they have counter seats looking into the kitchen. You get a peek of the behind the scenes work that go into making your meal! 

I ordered the chicken sisig which is their signature dish. It was well marinated and the lemon slice is the perfect cherry on top. The dish comes with a generous scoop of rice topped with a sunny side egg, and a slice of tomato and cucumber. I had a bite of the pork belly and that was delicious as well.

The price was fair for the amount of food per order. Definitely curious about their other dishes and their ube pie. Will come back for that :)
author: Mandi H.

description: Best chicken sisig ever. This place is SUPER small. You can barely walk inside but it's completely worth it. The food was extremely fresh. So tasty. So good. I will DEFINITELY be coming back for more.
author: Sammie C.

description: Delicious hole in the wall! Their filipino food is very comforting and brings back memories of my mom's cooking. The cooks/servers are very friendly and welcoming. The space is limited with about 8-10 seats facing the kitchen area. My friend and I ordered the lumpias and sisigsilog which came sizzling in a stoneware plate. The dish came with a side of rice and and a fried egg on top!
author: Sui N.

description:
Hidden gem of restaurant. My friend picked this place and I didn't realize it was in the tenderloin district. When I had seen we were turning on Jones Street I had my doubts on the food quality, but was greatly surprised. The location in not deep into Jones Street so I felt safe and the food was worth it. 

The menu is simple and my meal was a flavorful meat and the kitchen is in front of your eyes! I was awed by the dessert, the ube pie made my taste buds dance. I hope to go back to enjoy the intimate and cozy comfortable setting.
author: Susan O.

description: Been here a couple of times and each time was a great experience. Servers were polite and quick in serving our food. Portions are good enough. Seating space is limited. Over all great food. Love the lumpia and tocino w/ garlic rice and especially their bangsilog. My go to spot whenever around Union Square :)
author: Diann U.

description: This place is literally a hole in the wall!! This place is always my 1st stop every time I'm in town. Their sisig is a must try, also the pares mami, those two are my favorite, and of course pretty much everything here is good.
author: JM R.

description:
On our first day in SF, my boyfriend and I were starving but had no idea where to eat?? I remembered a good friend of mine recommended Tselogs and to my surprise it was only a 5 minute walk from our hotel! 

Tselogs is a tiny hole in the wall that probably seats 10 comfortably lol. We snagged some seats and were entertained by the chefs making our food right in front of us. As filipinos, we definitely had high expectations.. We ordered a large arroz caldo (childhood favorite) and a chicken sisig silog. OMG. The arroz caldo is exactly how I remembered it as a little girl. Comforting, aromatic, and delicious. The sisig was amazing too!!! I loved the garlic rice, the over easy egg, and the sizzling sisig that had both crunchy and chewy parts to it. I left Tselogs happy and full. 

Also!! They have an amazing throwback playlist! 

PLEASE OPEN A LOCATION IN LA!!
author: Jesse L.

description: Incredible incredible incredible! I want to keep this place a secret, but everyone needs to try it. My new favorite restaurant in the city.
author: Dexter H.

description:
I just loveeee hole in the wall places like this! Cheap & GOOD food, quick service, and a small hideout that doesn't seat too many. It kind of has this "izakaya" vibe that reminds me of Tokyo except it serves really tasty (albeit a bit oversalted Filipino food). For about $10-$13 pp you can get quite a good and filling portion. 

I ordered the tocilog - really really flavorful but just too salty and chicken sisig, also a bit too salty. However, portion sizes were decent and sated me. 

It's really small - not good for groups. Also the location is sketch but... *sigh* you're living in SF and it is the Tenderloin.
author: Cindy W.

description: Love the taste . Came here after clubbing around 2:00 am, and the waitress was super nice and accommodating . Only bad thing is the space , the place is tiny!!
author: Astrid M.

description:
SOOOOO SAD that Kare Ken is no more I think I was subconsciously boycotting this place.

It is a little less pretty (more wear and tear) than Kare Ken - which had a minimalist vibe (this place has more equipment and clutter.  But the meals were yummy. 

We had the signature chicken sisig, and one of the pork dishes - all the names are so complicated I cannot figure out which one. The sisig was the winner.  

The two guys there work hard and it a  bargain at about $9/meal. Unlike Kare Ken - they do NOT allow you to bring in adult beverages.

But I will be back,
author: Amy W.

description: Brought the family here since it had been a long time since having home cooked Filipino food.  The kids loved it and said it's like how Lola makes it. Clever idea of having garlic fried rice and a fried egg with each meal and then your choice of meat.  The sisig is on point.  Don't sleep in this place.
author: Darnell M.

description: Seriously delicious late night food. Try all the fried rice plates and don't forget you. An dine in or take it to go by ordering at the small window on the street
author: Chris S.

description: Pretty small place and I'm sure when it's crowded, probably best to even just call in and order to go so you wouldn't have to wait. The lechon (fried pork belly) with garlic rice and egg is so good! I'd highly recommend that one if you love pork belly. Proportions are on the smaller side in my opinion, especially for the price. I ordered the lechon dish and lumpia and it came out to around $20. I would come back again for the lechon though!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Nice late night spot for some comfort food. 

Staff were polite and nice. Cool that there is a small window open in the front for take out orders. Inside, seating is very tight, my opinion just take your food to go.  

Ordered longsilog, embutidosilog, and lechon kawali. Pretty basic being Filipino and growing up with this food. If you're new to these dishes just read the menu description. Nothing scary about these guys. If you want meat and rice with a sunny side egg, these choices are safe.
author: Adel O.

description:
I am so glad this place is open until 3am on Friday and Saturdays. My friends and I were looking for a place to eat after leaving the club at 2am and we were so happy to find Tselogs! I've only had Filipino food once before and it was okay since I didn't really know what to order. But this time, with the help of my friends and Yelp photos, I ordered the lechon kawali which is a daily special and not on the regular menu. I was blown away by how simple and delicious my meal was. They give you a decent amount of fried pork belly with a huge scoop of garlic rice and a perfect sunny-side egg. The pork belly was crispy and flavorful and the sauce was bomb! 

My boyfriend also ordered the lechon kawali but was able to add sweet marinated pork for an extra $3.99. Sooo good too. It's a small space so there's only bar-like seating but you can watch the cooks prepare your food. This was the best 'drunchie' meal I've had in a while and I can't wait to go back!!
author: Cecille W.

description: I'm convinced this place used to be a ramen bar based on the small space. I visited on a Saturday night at around 1am and there was a short line outside. Many random people walking past (gotta love SF). Was seated after about 10 minutes and I couldn't have been more pleased. Sat at the bar and was immediately served water. Got our food within 10 minutes and had the combo (better deal for your $!). I had the tapsilog and bangsilog bc I loooove Bangus (milkfish). Damn near Ate the whole fish minus the tail. the tapa was way sweeter than what I'm used to, so I wasn't too fond of that. But my friend had the sisigsilog (chopped fried chicken served in a cast iron) and hotsilog (Filipino hot dog). SISIGSILOG WAS SO GOOD. they actually took longer to serve the sisigsilog so the chef comped an extra plate of garlic fried rice. YUM. Perfect place to end a night out!
author: Cherrilyn B.

description: Great service, incredible food, and it's open till 3 am. You don't have to settle for something mediocre just because it's late night when Tselogs is around
author: Claire C.

description:
This is seriously a HOLE in the wall! It's a tiny little Filipino restaurant that cooks up some decent sisig! Ever since I've had Papa Urb's sisig, I've been searching for a Filipino restaurant locally that can make it just as good. Unfortunately, Tselogs didn't live up to that expectation. However, they do provide a nice sizzling sisig-silog skillet!

I came here on a Monday evening before attending my first Yelp event. When I walked in, I was greeted right away by one of the cooks. He gave me the menu and explained the items and the process. You pick one entrée and are able to add the "silog" portion which is a scoop of garlic rice topped with an egg. Since I was craving sisig, I decided to order the sisig-silog. As I mentioned before, this place is super tiny! There are no "tables" here per say. It's set up like a bar where you sit at the counter. It's not an ideal setup for a large group but a nice place to stop by for a quick dinner.

My food arrived and it was a sight for sore eyes! That skillet was sizzling up a storm! The smell radiated the little room and my mouth started watering. Per other Yelper's suggestions, I mashed the egg into the rice and mixed that into the sisig. My expectations were super high, especially after watching the grand sizzling entrance of my entrée. Although it was an eye catcher, the flavors just weren't up to par. It was definitely lacking something, but I couldn't quite figure out just what. I usually like my sisig with green onions, Sriracha sauce, and cream. I don't know if that is the Americanized way of eating it, but that's what I was looking for.  It had a decent flavor to it and the meat was hot and tender but it could have used more seasoning.

The portion size was just enough to fill you up. No leftovers, but it did the job. The cook checked in on me and refilled my water cup without me having to ask. He gave me a punch card that would allow me to gain a free entrée after so many visits. I was full after eating my sisig, but I really wanted to try the Halo Halo pie because I just love Halo Halo. Good luck finding parking here... and if you DO find parking, be careful as this place is located in the Tenderloin. Overall, it's a decent place to come and get sisig if you're in the area, but nothing special.
author: Shayla B.

description:
Weeeelll... What can I say about this place!? This is probably one of my favorite places in the area, if not my absolute fave. If you've never been here, this place is an absolute must.

I believe that I tried most things on the menu, and I've yet to find something I don't like. Their lumpias are a must, they're super fresh and very high quality. Their sissilog is also ridiculously good, but so is their fried chicken and pork belly. Even when it comes to desserts, their pies are 

Please do yourself a favor and go here!
author: Josh Giosue D.

description:
Great Food. Really Awful Service.

Truly, there is nothing worse than fantastic food that suffers due to terrible service.

The one running the register seems high and constantly misses or ignores things. The food takes way way way too long for fast food (15-30 minutes for rice?). Regardless of what you order, expect an obnoxious wait.

It really really pains me to say, but there is a clear and constant Asian bias. I've had (and watched) my food, order, or even place in line take back seat to Asian customers. I'd hesitate to put this here if it was just me. Unfortunately, I've seen it happen about a dozen times now :(

It's a damn shame these guys don't have their sh** together. Because when the food finally arrives through the cut of bad service and AZN cliques, it's really great. 

Update: Racist. Unfortunately, the place has become blatantly racist, much more than before. Asian or sit at the back of the bus. You'll notice a trend in good vs bad reviews.
author: M B.

description:
I'm not one to be easily swooned by Filipino food for reasons that I am Filipino myself and have grown bored of eating it everyday, but I must say that Tselogs wasn't something I could look the other way from. We were greeted and seated immediately, and served my bf and I two empty cups with a long bottle of water to start. The long table we sat at that watched the cooks reminded me of a ramen bar-it's really cute! 
We ordered Shanghai Lumpia, Longsilog ( a sweet pork sausage with rice and egg), Sisigsilog (bits of chicken and scallions stir fried together with rice and eggs), and Filipino Spaghetti. 

The shanghai Lumpia was a perfect starters appetizer of simple deep fried eggs rolls filled with meat and vegetables with a side of sweet and sour dipping sauce. I could tell they added a hint of banana ketchup to their sauce. Definitely a must try for people that are new to Filipino food! Very popular Filipino finger food.

The Longsilog plate consisted of 3 sweet sausages- 2 of them were the regular red ones and the 3rd one was the darker garlic ones because they ran out of the original ones toward the end of the night. The garlic one was much better than the sweet red ones in my opinion, so that was an unexpected liking in the end.
The sisigsilog was pretty tasty as well. They served it on a hot skillet with a side of lemon. The cook was nice enough to give my bf the helpful tip to mix his sunny side egg with the Sisig followed by a squeeze of lemon for the best consistency. Great tip! I've never eaten my Sisig that way, and i also never usually eat chicken Sisig (I always did pork, liver, ear, etc the freaky authentic way if I ever did with just lemon on it) but i loved the way it tasted regardless.

Now the best part was their Filipino Spaghetti. Served with spaghetti noodles, marinara, and cheese like most Italian spaghettis, Filipino spaghetti is much sweeter with added ground beef, hot dogs, sugar, and buttery noodles. It may sound strange at first but it is a MUST TRY (It is soo good- my friends that have never eaten Filipino food are always a fan). 

Overall, the portion sizes were pretty decent considering you spend $10-15 a plate. The customer service was great - the cook that helped us was a pretty nice guy! He was very attentive and helpful giving us a nice tips here and there to make our stay just as enjoyable as the taste of our food. Our wait time was minimal around 5-10 mins to get our food and they always checked up on us to make sure we were happy! The only disappointment I had was that their dessert menu didn't consist of real halo halo and the area was pretty small- not much room for tables and the bars to eat on were small.
author: Rissa K.

description: The embutidosilog (meat loaf) was quite good! Don't be put off by the location... not best of neighborhoods, but the restaurant is excellent. Tea/(hot chocolate) is self serve and you have to pay at the take out. The food is quick and delicious! I enjoy the meat log, but another good dish is the Singsilog (tasted a bit). Only thing I wanted a bit more of was some veggies and a little less rice, but other than that I'd recommend this place and dish :)
author: Scott B.

description:
If you're reading this because you're trying to figure out what to order at Tselogs, just stop... order anything and everything. EVERYTHING IS DELICIOUS.

Seriously though, if it's your first time here or your first experience with Filipino comfort food... I do always recommend getting their signature chicken sisig. It's ridiculously good. Not oily, well-marinated, comes sizzling with a lemon wedge on top (use it), garlic rice (inhale it), and a fried egg on top (mm mm). I don't have a single friend that's had it that hasn't gotten OBSESSED. 

And of course, get some lumpia wit that. And as hard as may be, save some room for a slice of ube macapuno pie or buko pie. 

Really, I seriously swear everything is good here.

The only downside is that the location is small with limited seating, but the food comes out pretty fast and I love watching all the action in the open kitchen. If you're a larger group or in a hurry, they have a to-go window that you can order takeout from :) 

It really doesn't get better than this!!
author: Ashley S.

description:
The Nurse Review by JM :)

S(ituation)- I came here with friends after a Friday night out around 13:00 and surprisingly, it wasn't crowded as I expected it to be yet ! 

B(ackground)-Late night Filipino eatery who serves mainly breakfast food such as longanisa, tocino, tapas, fried rice topped with an egg!
 
A(ssessment)-First impression is the restaurant itself is a hole in the wall! The food is great ! It's a fairly small place with not a lot of seating. I would suggest taking out your order to skip the wait! 

R(eccomendation)- Yes, I would recommend this place and I suggest ordering the longsilog or the tocilog! The portions we're large enough if you get the combination plate !
author: Jan M.

description:
got cizzokblocked from here thursday when i was suddenly rerouted to dinner elsewhere. but this saturday post-gym brunch i slayed just now was grrd so it worked out.

no clipboard join the LINE outside or if there isn't one walk tf in. minimal SEATING makes it tricky for groups of 3+ at peak times (mayb plan for takeout). sliiiiightly easier to get servers' ATTENTION at the bar vs sitting at the wall.

(^_^) Cornbisilog $11 (http://bit.ly/2w7NPIN)
comforttt fooddd i'm falling asleep.
partially crisp / toasted texture nice idea.

(^_^) Coconut Water $3 (http://bit.ly/2iBuew2)
cold. refreshing. w pulp.

(-_^) Lumpia Shanghai x12 $7 (http://bit.ly/2wRfKO5)
light, crisp, not bad. add vinegar.

(-_^) Embutidosilog $10 (http://bit.ly/2wemGCA)
blended sweetmeat.

(!_!) Vinegar $0 (http://bit.ly/2vyVBYF)
it's here! why do so many filipino restos not put this on tables?

bzs will say i should've gotten the sizzling chicken (noksilog) or pork belly (lechon) or yadayada but no pork belly that day and i never had sizzling dishes at home growing up. in my literal childhood kitchen it was chicken adobo, dinuguan, balut (yes muhfuhs i said balut), corned beef, bbq ribs, or other usa southern foods. so for me the corned beef is the one that brings daydreams & the itis. :p

3.5 stars
author: Dan B.

description:
Filipino breakfast is honestly the bees knees.
