I live for corn beef & garlic rice topped with eggs in the morning and this place is just another level of deliciousness. 
Being a Filipino American I am embarrassed to say I had never tried Sisig before my visit here, but everyone and anyone...ORDER THE CHICKEN SISIG. 
Just an explosion of flavor in your mouth.
Order 2 with some garlic rice because you'll probably want more.
Location is pretty small with a bar type, knee to knee seating so come early. Service is fast & very attentive. You'll leave very satisfied.
author: Amy D.

description:
I thought this place was alright. The food is really good value (large portions for $10), the place is distinctive, and the service is great, but I didn't find the tselogs themselves that delicious. 

I do recommend this place if you're hungry and want to try something distinctive. The staff here are all super enthusiastic, knowledgeable, and the restaurant does a good job highlighting what's popular help you make a decision. The ambiance, contrary to what the TL location might lead you to believe, is clean, cozy (but not uncomfortable), and very ramen bar-like.

That said, I really wish I liked the taste of the tselogs more.
author: Amy G.

description:
Found this place on yelp during our quick layover. We are vegetarians and they have one dish for us "Pancit Bihon" which is the noodle with vegetables (and meat if you eat meat).  We ordered a garlic rice and an extra egg on the side along with an extra egg for the noodles. We finished with UBe pie and the coconut pie. 

The food was good.
author: Cindy W.

description:
Tilapia -overcooked (left in the fryer too long)
Aroz Caldo/filipino porridge - delicious
palabok- delicious
The 3 dishes I ordered were authentic.

Space is small, so you're eating at the counter or taking it to-go.
I'd come back if I were in the area, but I won't come out of my way for it.
author: Angelica C.

description:
Solid Filipino silog options - various meats to choose from to go with your rice and egg. I ordered the lechon kawali (friend pork belly) for $12.99. The meat was great, but felt like everything on the plate wasn't as warm (temperature wise) as it could have been. The "garlic" rice was also lacking in garlic.

Plates average between $9 and $12 which isn't bad for the amount of food you get. In addition to silog, they also had a few other noodle options (with and without soup) and a generous list of desserts.

Very small location - not good for big groups. Seating reminded me of sitting at a sushi bar. Located in a sorta sketchy area, esp if you're walking up from Market.

Huge props to the guy who plates the food. I think I saw him try to perfectly stack the lechon kawali maybe 10 times before he got it to stay. Amazing.
author: Kristine S.

description: My favorite place to eat Filipino food in SF is at this place! It's a hole in the spot but moves pretty fast. I recommend bringing no more than 4 people to eat here at one time. You can also order it to-go as well....but recommend eating it there for the full experience. They also play good music while eating! The chicken arroz caldo and corned beef are my favorite dishes. The ube buko pie was pretty good too but not memorable.
author: Justin T.

description: This is a small place, but the food was absolutely delicious! I ordered the Sisigsilog as some of the other reviewers recommended and enjoyed it thoroughly.
author: Chris F.

description: I like the small size of this restaurant. Food wise I wasn't impressed by the food nor was I disappointed.
author: Marcus M.

description: Maybe it's because I'm not a huge fan of buying food that I feel like I could make at home, but I thought that this food was just okay. I'm going to give it three stars though because my fiancé loves it and keeps on bringing me back haha. I didn't think that the coconut pie was worth getting. The pork belly was not on the menu but the sauce that came with it was just from a jar. And the lemongrass chicken on the hot plate was okay but mainly because I'm a sucker for fried eggs on rice. Maybe I need to try something on the menu that's more complicated?
author: Mora O.

description: Looked this place up on Yelp last night and saw it was only a few blocks from my hotel. Almost didnt go, but i am sssssssooooooooo glad i did. I always try to find some good Filipino food when I'm in SF and this isbthe best I've had. I had a combo plate with pork belly, milkfish, and garlic rice. AMAZING. The fish was perfectly fried and the pork belly melts in your mouth. The rice was also really good and very garlicky. If you're not a fan of big garlic taste, you're gonna want to ask for plain rice. I'm only here for a couple more days, but I'm definitely going back.
author: Alex M.

description: The place is small, I went there to purchase lumpia to go, the lumpia is ok but sweet chili sauce no taste at all, and they didn't give me napkin :(.
author: Endah T.

description:
Came here around midnight on a Friday night after doing a late check-in at our hotel.  This place is tiny and had to ask someone where it was located (and the guy kept bugging us for money as he told us the location, he wouldn't leave us alone until we gave him $1 but that's downtown for ya late at midnight).  The seating inside is very limited so my group decided to order to go and eat it back at our hotel.
My group got the longsilog Hamonado style, the sisigsilog, and the pares silog. 
The longsilog is tasty, just like how longanisa is supposed to be.  The sisigsilog is very different compared to sisig at home in LA, it's more on the vinegar side. It tasted good to me and I love how the green onion adds flavor to it; however, a friend didn't like it because it was more on the vinegar side. 
The Pares Silog is hands down the best here!!! It's my first time trying Pares and my first time even hearing about it.  It's beef that has a sweet Unami flavor to it, not like tocino where it's just sweet.  My group and I all wanted to come back here for the Pares Silog.  Try it! You won't be disappointed with it!
author: Lyn T.

description:
Thoroughly enjoyed this place. I've never had Filipino food before, so I can't say for sure whether it was authentic or not, but the restaurant food was delicious. 

We ordered the lumpia, which the waiter highly recommended. He said that they were made from scratch in-house, and they were amazing! A bit oily, but that is too be expected from a fried dish. I don't remember how many lumpia the dish came with, but I would say around 10. They are bite sized and easy to eat. It comes with a red sauce that initially looks spicy, but is in fact, a bit tangy. 

For my entree, I ordered the sisigsilog. It had a heart next to it, so I assume it is somebody's favorite. The overall dish was pretty good, but I felt the chicken to be VERY oily and quite salty. Again, I'm not sure if this is what the dish should be like, but the flavor was a bit too much for me. However, I still- for the most part- enjoyed my order.

My friend ordered a similar dish but with marinated pork. I think I liked his dish better! It was so flavored and didn't taste as oily. 

The portions are pretty big and the dishes were definitely worth it. Highly recommend stopping by.
author: Christine H.

description: I ordered the Sisigsilog which came as sizzling chicken with garlic rice. The chicken was tasty and I loved how it stayed hot because of the sizzling pan it came out on. The rice was also delicious as it wasn't just plain rice. I also tried the pancit bihon which had various veggies such as carrots and cabbage with the noodles. Tasty, but the noodles were a bit too soggy for me.
author: Jeana Y.

description:
I've never had Filipino food until this place and now I'm in love!! Not going to lie, when I first saw the pictures I was hesitant to go because of the presentation.. rice with an egg on top and some meat? But decided to go because my boyfriend insisted and now I am happy I went! 

My boyfriend and I ordered the lumpia, bowl of soup and combination plate with Sisigsilog (sizzling chicken) and the sweet sausage. Everything was super good and flavorful. My favorite was the sisigsilog and if you're a first timer to Filipino food, I would recommend it!
author: Michelle L.

description:
I LOVE Tselogs! Use to frequent the Daly CIty location a while back when i lived in DC.

The location for SF is in the tenderloin but easy to get to by public transit. Open late!! 

I always go with the SIsigsilog. You cannot go wrong with that, its one of their most popular dishes. Comes out on a sizzling plate served with garlic rice and an egg! Yum. The place is super small, no tables all counters. The staff is great. Prices are also reasonable for SF. $15 minimum for credit card.
author: Daniel S.

description: This spot was probably one of my favorite meals in SF - and much less expensive than many of the others! If the space was larger, I would have come back to read and linger -- but it was quite busy and bustling. Food was delicious and service friendly and fast. Will return!
author: Bridgette T.

description: Every item on their menu is great. The spaghetti is surprisingly delicious, the porridge was very savory and the garlic rice is fragrant.
author: Shiya L.

description: Omg I love this place. The zigling chicken and the pork belly both killed me. They tasted sooooo good! Love their garlic rice too. Very nice spot, service was great too.
author: Charmie L.

description:
I came here late one Friday night and found this itty bitty restaurant to be packed.  Not a fan of it's location but have come to find that there are a lot of hidden gems in the Tenderloin.  I would have never thought that Filipino food would come about in a trendy and popular way considering I've grown up eating this my whole life.  

We ordered the Tapsilog with garlic rice and Lumpiang Shanghai.  Great tasting comfort food however would have liked their portion sizes to be a little bit more generous.  I don't think the lumpia was enough to have me feeling full.  

Not a place I would think to visit again just because I think Filipino food tastes better home cooked.  C'mon, you know no one does it better than yo mama! Amirite?!
author: Jann B.

description:
Flashback to my pre teen days.  I was running around with my playmates, oblivious to anything that was happening around me.  I could sense that it was getting late, and it would be time for dinner soon, but I didn't care.  I just want to squeeze in every last bit of play time.  Then I heard my grandma calling me.

Ronnie!!!  She is one of the few people that have the privilege of calling me like that.

I run back to the house, but instead of the comfortable surroundings of her kitchen, I'm seated at a long counter next to my grownup playmates.  I've been transported to current day at Tselogs. 

The surroundings are different, however the smell, taste, and comfort of grandma's cooking has come back to life.  Yes, this is definitely a regular stop on my early dinner circuit
author: Ron L.

description:
There's something very comforting about a plate of fragrant garlic rice with a perfect sunny side up egg on top.  The chicken sisig was also bright in flavors, especially with the squeeze of fresh lemon on top. 

While comforting, the meal also felt really heavy.  There wasn't enough vegetables on that plate (one slice of tomato and one slice of cucumber).  Maybe take it to go and pair it with a side salad or something green to lighten up the meal a bit.  

Pro-Tip:  Stir the chicken on the hot plate when you get it.  The bottoms start to burn if you leave it on.
author: Jenny L.

description:
So glad I randomly stumbled upon the place.

The space is cozy and cute - reminiscent of a tiny sushi bar restaurant. The staff is super friendly. My waiter walked me through the menu and made sure I'd be happy with my order since I didn't know much about Filipino food.

I can't remember the names of what I got, but I got the sizzling chicken (their most popular) and the sweet marinated pork. The ground chicken came out in a sizzling dish and a lemon on top, which I was told to squeeze onto the chicken and mix it all together. Holy food heaven this was SO good. The chicken was juicy, zesty and mouth-watering good. I preferred this way over the pork. I found the pork to be a bit dry and overly sweet. And the garlic rice topped with an egg? YUM. 

Great experience. Can't wait to try the other dishes.
author: Sue C.

description: Had this after a really late event -- it's awesome how late it's open. The place is really small but the food was absolutely amazing. Definitely, recommend the Sisig. Just FYI because the pan is sizzling, I would keep stirring so it doesn't burn but other than that, it was amazing.
author: Augustus Y.

description:
Yes. Filipino food. 

It was a great cheap meal we wanted to try and have before a night on the town. I've never had Filipino food cooked by a mom or grandmother so I dont know if this is authentic, but it was delicious. 

They put an egg on the rice - delicious and with the meat (fried chicken for him and chicken adobo for me). So good! 

Protip: chicken adobo
author: Nina Y.

description:
We started with a dozen lumpia, freshly fried and piping hot.

We eat got a silog plate, and I opted for the chicken sisig. Sizzling and well-marinated, and it didn't taste very oily like other ones I've had. My dinnermates got longanisa, lechon, and beef tapa, and we shared all the meats. My favorites were probably the chicken sisig and lechon.

The silog and egg was perfectly portioned, with a side of cucumber and tomato.

Try the banana ketchup!

I'll definitely be back! Tiny space with about seven seats on the counter, so it'll be luck of the draw if you have a bigger group.
author: Kevin L.

description: Didn't even know this branch existed until a friend from Norway mentioned this.  It was a small place (15-20) bar like seating compared to other branches. Got the combosilog with bangus and sisig.  Presentation was good. I like the little skillet they used for the sisig. Place was clean and servers were attentive. Orders came out fast! Must try
author: Ro N.

description:
I am not an expert in Filipino cuisine..but I have eaten many a home cooked meal at my friend's " Auntie's House" and an old Girl friend's home cooking. 

We're  talking Dinugan, Kare Kare, pata, pancit etc.

Tselogs was a fun place to grab a quick meal. The employees and diners were all in good spirits and it was great  chatting with both.

Where Tselogs falls short was: 

My lechon special was pretty much all fat.

 I sat there for 15 minutes while my rice and over easy egg just sat there sans Lechon...not the best way to serve it. 

Cleanliness is not the priority

Most dishes were listed as 8-9 dollars ( and neglecting good ol Tony Bourdains' advice) but my daily special was 12-13 bucks. It was not worth it.

I got to give them props from opening in the Tenderloin and doing the egg over easy right but I just don't feel this place.
author: David G.

description:
Bro, why have i never stumbled here sober or drunk?!?!?
First off, I have been to the daly city location. That place is convenient because it's quiet, open late. That being said, this place is everything. They said this is the main location and they will be opening another one on valencia where I will live at every night after a bar HAHA.
We have the sisig, pork adobo, and lenchon. Silog style of course. The adobo was yummy, a lot of sauce. A bit salty but it was probably because that's the  only one we had a la carte.
The sisig was flavorful, nicely cooked, not overcooked or burned.Lenchon was wonderful- it was crunchy on the outside and nice and soft on the inside.
I recommend this place. You might have a wait since it's a super small spot, seats probably less than 20 people.
author: francis c.

description:
When this location popped up, I was all excited because it is only blocks away from where I live. So it saves the commute time instead of trekking out to their original location in Daly City. This location has that nice intimate feel, having only a select amount of seats at their bar top. The food is still the great Tselogs that we all know, except they are a bit more minimal to what they offer versus their OG location. 
I love the convenience of this new location, and that they offer the top dishes on their menu that they were well known for at their OG location EXCEPT for the spaghetti, which I was so bummed out on when I found out that they didn't have that on their menu when I showed up. But honestly, this place is so great. 

Thank you for bringing this location to the Tenderloin. You have some proud and happy patrons loving this new spot!
author: Nick A.

description: I ate at this place couple of months ago so old review. Came here because of rave reviews. We thought the food was just just okay.  Nothing too memorable other than it being kind of a unique hole in a wall.
author: Eric S.

description: Bomb. Now I don't have to drive to Lucky Chances for a good silog. Only like 12 seats but you can order to go.
author: Gina R.

description: This place is out of this world. Imagine just getting out of an 80s concert and being really hungry... Show up to tselogs for some beef silog... Mmm tasty.
author: Joey C.

description:
Been looking for a Filipino restaurant in the city. Found this place on yelp and decided to give it a try.

The place is small so there is limited seating. We went late at night around 9pm on a Wednesday and there were people in their but there wasn't a wait. We got seated immediately. If it's too crowded you can also order to go which they have a walk up window for on the outside of the restaurant. Really good option to have.

I ordered the chicken dish which came on a sizzling hot plate and lumpia. They were both really amazing. The food here is great.

I would come back here again! And they open really late!
author: Scott T.

description: This place is still so good one year later. We got the arroz caldo, the sisigsilog, the marinated pork, and the bancit pihon. Wow everything was so good, especially the arroz caldo which is this savory rice porridge and the bancit pihon which is this stir fry noodle dish on another level.
author: Shabnam E.

description: It's a small space but filled with friendliness. The servers were all sweet. The lumpia was crispy. The garlic rice was just the right amount of garlicky goodness. They have lots of options and everything looked good.
author: Eve C.

description:
The only thing I missed when I left Daly City was the authentic Filipino food. My two favorite places were Fil-Am Cuisine and Tselogs. Oh, many a recoveries from drunk adventures were spent with my old roommate at Tselogs. The Daly City location is open from 8:30am until the wee hours of the morning most days, making it the perfect place for late night munchies or early morning hangovers.

Words cannot express how happy I was to hear that Tselogs had opened a San Francisco location. I was wary at first and careful not to get my expectations up too high, but every secret high expectation was blown out of the water when I tried my favorite Sisigsilog dish, which comes with sisig, rice, egg, and a few fresh slices of tomatoes and cucumber. So satisfying!! The sisig comes on a sizzling plate with lemon to give it that extra burst of flavor.

If you like Filipino food and have never tried Tselogs, do yourself a favor and head there right now. Like... Right now. They're probably open. Actually you might have to wait since there are only a few seats inside, unlike the Daly City location, but you can always take the food to-go. I might do that next time, in addition to ordering a slide of pie for dessert!
author: Stefanie C.

description:
This is a late night Filipino food joint in downtown SF that is open until 3:00AM on Fridays/Saturdays! Any easy-to-eat food spot open late in downtown is great especially if you're not in the mood for a dirty dog or something. I simply like the fact that this place exists however here are my 2 gripes:

1) The food is mediocre--could be more flavorful. I went with the Sisigsilog which was alright. My friends went the Tocilog and Longsilog which both looked/tasted better than what I had.
2) The dining area is SMALL--I mean, that adds the hole-in-the-wall charm and exclusivity but beware of this because if you have a big party you'll likely be getting food to-go.

Otherwise, what a great idea to have some decently tasty Filipino food in the heart of SF Union Square when you're looking for good eats before heading home!
author: Marlon T.

description:
Good, seemed extra crowded with youngster students and tech bros (ie loud conversations) 

I thought the portions were small but makes since given the reasonable prices. 

My chicken sisig was a tad salty, IMO, but I'm curious what the other dishes taste like. The lumpia was standard yet yummy. 

I'll be back on a day/time that is less crowded than Thursday night at 10pm, service will probably be better too!

Overall worth a visit!
author: Pedro W.

description: Amazing Filipino restaurant with a very Japanese Ramen house feel. Great simple menu with many traditional ingredients and common foods for both Filipino to American-Filipinos.
author: Jeff C.

description:
This is a very small unique Filipino restaurant in Tenderloin (don't worry, the location is fine). There are long counters instead of single tables, so expect to be in close proximity with other diners. It's a bit hard to describe without a picture, so check out some of the pics others have posted. I am not that familiar with Filipino food, but I found the dishes tasty and filling.

What I liked:
* "Hipster hole in the wall" is how I would describe this place. I really liked the vibe here.
* Dishes arrived with nice presentation and were filling and fairly good.

What I disliked:
* I had high expectations for the food coming in and the dishes fell a bit short in terms of taste. I found my main chicken dish to be a bit too salty and had to drink lots of water throughout the meal. Granted, I don't have much experience with Filipino food, so I'm definitely not the best critic for it.
author: Michael M.

description: Really good small whole on the wall Filipino restaurant. Service was really good and the food was amazing. I really recommend the sisig, that one was my favorite. Definitely will be returning whenever I come back to SF.
author: Alexander T.

description: Very tasty Filipino food. The interior is no frills bar style seating, so it's a good place for a quick, casual bite. I had the chicken dish as it came recommended. It was served with a nice sized portion of rice. The flavor of the chicken was excellent, and the meal left me very satisfied.
author: Michael S.

description: Absolutely delicious. I order the Tocisilog with a portion of Lumpia. Both were incredible. I've been to the Philippines a few times and this place serves it up properly. Great portions, full of flavor, simple ingredients. So happy I took a chance. It's very small and hard to find. I walked past it like 3 times.
author: Clements J.

description: Got the porridge and braised beef. Friendly staff and great food. Highly recommend stopping by for a quick lunch.
author: Qui C.

description:
Very glad to know that there's a nearby Filipino eatery in downtown SF. The place is very small and not in great location but happy with the quality of food. Ordered sisigsilog and Pares. The sisigsilog was a lil salty for me but the Pares was delicious. This place is good enough to satisfy some Filipino food cravings. 

PS:
**If you want to advertise a business, just bring a sticker of that business and they stick it outside the freezer. 
Great Free advertisement offer.
author: Kath S.

description: Food available at 2am?! And breakfast for dinner?? Count me in! This is truly a gem in the city. Although it was Halloween weekend and the line was insane, me and my party of 10 decided to place an order to-go. My boyfriend ordered the embotidolog which was eggs and a popular Filipino meatloaf. He also ordered the sisilog, which he devoured in the car in minutes. I ordered the tapsilog which was a sweetly marinated pork with egg and a side of garlic rice. The meal was really tasty. I only wish I got to enjoy it right away fresh off the pan. My brothers said their dish was too chewy as if it was overcooked. Aside from this, my food was tasty and affordable. I only hope they expand to an area with more seating.
author: Brittany D.

description: Always quick, delicious, and satisfies my Filipino cravings. Only place in SF that I can rely on to do this, otherwise have to head south.
author: Josie A.

description:
The problem with Filipino food is that you'll rarely ever find a restaurant that will ever be as good as some home cooking.  I enjoy Filipino food but we usually just wait to go to his parents' or relatives' to eat it.  Of course there's things that family rarely makes and you have to go out for such as sisig, silogs, etc.  I was craving Filipino food so hard and decided to hit up Tselogs for lunch at work the other day.

I'm so happy that they opened their second location within walking distance of my office.  This spot is much smaller than their DC restaurant; it's narrow with some counter seating.  I called in my order of chicken sisig silog and was quoted about 10-15 minutes.  It was a little over $10 with tax and they gave me a $1 off coupon for my next order.  

Took it back to my office to indulge.  It's a bit smaller than what they give in DC but still just as tasty.  My egg yolk wasn't runny but sometimes that's the risk you take when you get to go.  There was a small bone though that I bite into like my second bite.  I like how they use chicken instead of pork so it's a little less fatty.  Their sisig has a little bit of a twist to it too with the patis but it's not overwhelming.  I was chatting up with the cashier there and he said that they have daily specials, so ask about them when you order.  

I'll be back for another silog or their delicious Filipino spaghetti.
author: Cat C.

description:
New location, well at least for me. They said they opened about 9 months ago. Super convenient since we were coming from a show in the city and this was nearby, yay! I was craving it and almost drove to Daly City to their other spot. Oh and I love the exterior, such a trendy entrance. Thank god for a place that serves tselogs till 3am. 

Their sisigsilog s on point! Chicken sisig is creamy, dressed with chicharon and green onion. The portion size is plenty and I love the take out packaging, it's in a secure container rather than the flip top version. After an hour of transporting, it was still hot and no spillage or a steamy/wet bag. 

Of course parking is tough around there. If you plan on a drive by/take out, call in the order and it'll be ready in 10 minutes.
author: Lorelyn P.

description: The food and the service in Tselogs is really good. I would recommend this restaurant to my friends. The Lechon Kawali Silog tastes awesome.
author: Huan M.

description: Good chicken sisigsilog with garlic rice and fried egg. Rice is a bit too hard and needs some more water. Good flavor overall. Just wish the entree can provide some veggies (disregard that one slice of cucumber and tomato) and not just meat and rice. Probably Filipino foods are not very big on sautéed veggies.
author: Lena H.

description:
Picture it: perfectly crisp and tasty lumpia Shanghai, the delightful scent of garlic rice frying, and original Pilipino music playing in the background.  Throw in the oddly warm 60 degree Indian summer evening, and I could almost fool myself into believing I was enjoying a meal in the Philippines.  If it was a rare cool winter evening that is since SF summer equals Philippines winter.  

This was my first visit to the Tendernob location and I plan to be a regular because I am a proud Filipino who loves his motherland.  I recommend getting the combo because it's hard to just pick one main item and you can get two items for just $4 more.  Lastly, I have to mention the buko pie.  It's hard enough finding good buko pie in the Philippines so I wasn't expecting much but it was so good! Adding ice cream is a must.  Next time I have to try the ube pie.  But bottom line: check them out!
author: Lance D.

description: Fun, unique atmosphere, the best part of the meal was the minestrone soup. Really good soup. I ordered a cheese appetizer and my entrée was the homemade three cheese ravioli. I enjoyed my meal and the service was very good.
author: Jason J.

description:
New favorite simple dinner place! 

This place is best for takeout, since there's not much seating. So far, I've had the rice plates (chicken and beef) as well as their chicken rice porridge. The porridge was good, but I think I prefer the rice plates.

Service was friendly and the workers are pretty relaxed, but also work in a timely manner. 

I can't wait to come back!
author: Sao B.

description: So good! Our favorite restaurant from our trip to SF. You can't the the price and what you get for the price is more than worth it. We had the tocilog and tapsilog, highly recommend both! Make a trip over, you won't regret it.
author: Heather H.

description:
The food here was delicious! Was pleasantly suprised. The food reminded me of what I've had when I was younger. This restaurant is the definiton of comfort filipino food.

I highly recommend the sisigsilog. It had so much flavour and it goes well with the garlic rice. I also like dropping a small amount of the seasoning (knorr seasoning in the restaurant) on my rice to give it more flavour. The only thing that I wasnt fond of was the lechon as it seemed a bit fatty, otherwise the food was good. I would go back again on my next visit.
author: Lea M.

description:
Food's just worthy of the price. Less 1 star for uncompetitive service; Cashier Anne or Anna (?) needs more training. She's totally gorgeous but not very fast in grasping and can barely meet customer demands. We're a group of 9 people when we ate here and paying was a totally chaos. She was so confused when wanted to pay in 3 separate checks, we even told her that even before she started taking our orders. We saw her put our orders in different checks but at the end, she kept on insisting that we can't as we came in as a group. As if she wanted us to come one by one and pretend to not know each other just for her to understand that we're paying separately. It took us around 15 minutes just trying to make her understand, but after all the time she took, she still did not get it. We ended up paying altogether just to get moving.


Ps. I know, we could have thought of just paying it altogether in one card, but we thought it was too simple for her not to understand.

Pss. We were traveling so we're tight on our personal budget that's why we wanted to pay separately.
author: Nica E.

description:
After clubbing, we were starving and looking for something open by our hotel. Yelp led us to Tselogs and I'm glad it did!

Outside there was a bouncer, which I could always appreciate.  Inside there was bar seating and a few tables.  Casual diner feel. 

I had the porridge and it was perfect!! It came out piping hot, and stayed that way the entire time. Nice and thick, but with the rice cooked down nice and creamy. 

My husband ordered the fried chicken and also the milk fish.  The fried chicken came out raw, and it was closing time, so they took it off the bill for us.  The milkfish was really good.

Perfect for late night drunken eats! We'll be back!
author: Vi Y.

description:
Ugh. I hate to give them such a low score cuz I really wanted to support my peoples. But there were a number of things that turned me off to this place.

I've been wanting to come here for lunch for a while now because it's very hard to find legit Filipino food in the city that is not "fusion" when you need to satisfy a craving. That being said. I'm half Filipino but I was raised by my Filipino grandma. Obviously no one can ever compare to her cooking.. in my eyes.

I decided to wait until after 2pm to come here to avoid any crowd, seeing from the reviews that this place is small. 

Arrived and only 3 people in the establishment sitting at the counter. I had no idea one was a worker eating lunch until she finished and headed behind the counter. 

So here's my cons:

1) The door was left open. Helllooo... tenderloin? Flies all over the place. 
2) The "stools" at the counter are basically wooden boxes. SO UNBELIEVABLY UNCOMFORTABLE. Seriously. I can't even explain how much the seat alone ruined my lunch.
3) I ordered lumpia and bangsilog. Lumpia was decent. My garlic fried rice was so bland :( I had to add salt and pepper. And I had to ask the lady for vinegar to go with my bangus.
4) I asked for a to-go container which the outside of the box was dirty. Gross. At the same time when I asked for the box I also asked to pay. The lady never came back to give me a check. She was counting her register and organizing her receipts for the longest. Service was really non-existent.

I will try it again for take out perhaps when I get a bad craving again. ‍
author: M E.

description:
I love Tselogs for it's tasty food, quick/efficient/friendly service, and good pricing. 

I would recommend the chicken sisiglog that comes with the garlic rice (drooool, so tasty!!!) as well as their buko pie with a side of ice cream.

The place is tiny with bar seating (about 6 seats near the register, and maybe another 4 behind it).  Typically the line moves somewhat fast.

Love this place!!! Def want to visit the more spacious Daly City location, since my boyfriend isn't the biggest fan of this neighborhood and won't come with me here.
author: Alison H.

description:
I'm a person who likes to eat breakfast for lunch and dinner. If I could, I'd do it all the time (or at least, most of the time). I'm also a big fan of Filipino-style breakfast, particularly the "-silog" dishes, which is comprised of garlic rice, egg, and some kind of meat or fish.

So I happen to be walking by one evening, and I notice this logo with an egg on it. And based on the name of the place, I quickly concluded it was a Filipino joint. I peeked into this tiny place and see people eating in there. And not just Filipinos, mind you. But I see also non-Filipinos! I mean, c'mon, Filipino food, as beloved as it is within the Filipino community, hasn't had the same mainstream acceptance as say, Thai & even Vietnamese cuisine. So to see non-Filipinos in there suggested to me that this place was worth checking out, if they are able to draw people who might not have a Pinoy palate.

As I enter with my companion, I see non-Filipinos wolfing down sisig. Okay, you know that's gotta be good, considering that I myself don't even eat sisig normally.

I ordered the bangsilog (milkfish), some lumpia, and washed it down with a slice of Filipino egg pie. That hit the spot!

I'll definitely come back and try the other dishes next time.
author: Crissy C.

description: id rather wait to go home and cook my own version of tapsilog not gonna recommend this place coz i myself was not satisfied their price is not reasonable way too expensive for the quality of the food they serve sorry but just have to say my opinion it shouldn't be that  hard to make it good its just how the meat is not fresh and not marinated good
author: Maryan A.

description:
Cozy little restaurant on the border of Union Square and the Tenderloin.  Literally just two counters, so don't plan to come with a large crowd.  Lots of tasty meat options; every main dish comes with garlic rice and a fried egg.  Very rich and filling; great comfort food in the neighborhood.

Sisigsilog: So delicious!  The sizzling chicken bits were full of spices and vinegary tang.  Loved that the garlic rice was really garlicky; I could see the garlic clove bits in the rice mound.  And, of course, the signature runny fried egg was a nice gooey touch to it all.

Lumpia: Pretty standard.  The minced meat tasted a tad more savory than the typical lumpia.  Also, their sauce looked like they jazzed it up, instead of pouring directly from a bottle.
author: Adam B.

description:
Incredibly chill spot with first date vibes.

Would highly recommend ordering the Sisilog with a side of Lumpia. Extremely delicious and filling :))

Thanks!
author: Dipesh D.

description:
Foodgasm comes to mind ... ummm ... yea. 

A cute little spot in the Tenderloin that seats 16 people at best, they are serving some delicious philipino comfort food. It brings me back to my childhood when I used to visit my best-friends family just to eat lumpia, adobo, chocolate meat, all while playing some dominoes with nana and her whiskey drinking crew. 

Since this was my first visit, they recommended the chicken sisisilog, and I opted for an extra egg. I dug how they brought out the garlic rice and eggs first, with the sizzling cast iron with sisisilog right after. 

Sweet, salty, tangy, satisfying, its everything you want it to be, and so much more. As I mentioned, it brought me back to a special time in my life, and I can't wait to make my way through their menu for more flashes down memory lane.
author: Roman V.

description: This is probably the best place to get filipino food, every place is ok in the food but it just taste better in this fine establishment, my wife likes the food also I'll probably go back here every week my wife loves Filipino food especially this place five star and see you next time delicious food
author: Alex W.

description:
Wanted to love it so bad!!! Ended up liking..Service was awesome; girl at counter was very friendly and helpful with menu...

Ordered off recommendation...a chicken dish served in a mini cast iron skillet with a fried egg. Flavorful, but a bit rich/greasy for my liking. 

Lumpias came out a bit too greasy as well--lots of flavor but just a bit too heavy.

All in all a decent spot, in no way a bad experience--may have walked in with my expectations a bit elevated...not every day I get to enjoy Filipino cuisine.
author: Sean W.

description:
So glad we stumbled upon this place during my last visit to SF.  We walked up and noticed that it was a small diner-like restaurant.  We waited about 20 minutes, and immediately put in our order once we were sat at the counter.  The food came out quickly, and everything was delicious.  

I highly recommend the Chicken Sisig & Garlic Fried Rice -- those were amazing!  I'll be back to try more items next time I visit.
author: Jan M.

description:
Wow. I wish I had Tselogs closer to home because I'd easily be here every week. They get the whole comfort food concept down, first and foremost with the cozy and intimate space inside. It's nothing "fancy," the cooks don't put on a show or do any other corny thing, but there's something so warming about watching your dishes come to life in front of you.  We came in at around 11 and had the place to ourselves, which made the homely experience that much more pleasant.

We ordered the palabok, chicken sisig silog, and the special lechon.  My favorite was the sisig - who cares if it didn't have peppers?  Flavors were rich, the chicken was equal parts tender and crispy from the sizzling plate, and mixing in the egg on top put it over the top.  I've never had palabok before, and after trying it I'm not sure I could eat an entire order, but I loved the acidity that cut through the dominant shrimp flavor in the sauce.  Lechon is lechon is heaven and a heart attack in the wings.  Plus, the garlic rice that came with the sisig and lechon was top notch and later cleared a path in front of me while walking in Union Square (kidding).

The menu is pretty simple, but don't let that discourage you in any way.  If these dishes are representative of what Tselogs offers on the whole, you're in for a treat.  I will do my darndest to be back here and go in on some less traditional offerings like the "spamsilog" and "cornbisilog."
author: Brennan L.

description: Soooooo good! Was in the city celebrating my anniversary and had to stop here!! I had bangus, lechon, chicken sisig and lumpia. None of the dishes disappointed. So much food, had left overs the next day good/friendly and prompt customer service. Will definitely return when I can
author: M D.

description:
Simple and good. The place is a tiny lil hole in the wall with limited seating so be ready to wait, get it to go, or maybe if you get lucky enough you'll have a nice lil spot to stay for a bit. Sitting in the place you're so close to everything cooking that all you do is absorb smells from everything. The guys in the back and the server were friendly, and checked on us frequently. We were also at the counter so it was pretty easy for them to pass by and check.

I had ordered an order of the pork lumpia and the vegetarian bihon. The lumpia were fried nicely, not overdone. The sauce they give you is like a spicy sweet n sour sauce which worked well. The bihon was good although I expected a bit more food for 8 bucks. Definitely use the lemon on the side. It works really well with the spices that are used. Fair warning there isn't much as far as vegetarian options.
author: David C.

description:
This is my first review on Yelp. I had to come here and say how amazing and authentic this place is! It feels like family.

P.S. the bangus was bomb!!!!
author: Stefano D.

description:
Bomb. Absolutely bomb. The garlic rice, the poached egg, the pancit--all worth it. The location is tiny with two rows for seating and an open kitchen. The only reason this place doesn't receive 5 stars is because my mother was missing her egg with her order (which negates the namesake of the restaurant). Other than that, Tselogs is amazing. 

Ordered: Sisiglog, plain rice & egg, and  vegetable pancit.
Must order: The pancit which is fresh and made-to order. Tons of vegetables and crazy flavorful without being greasy or heavy.
author: Hope J.

description:
This was my first time here and we came kind of late.  I think around 10pm.  Anyway, the place is really small... There's bar seating along the wall and a few stools (maybe 6?) facing the kitchen.

What I liked about this place is that I felt like I was hanging out with family because of the intimacy of the place.  We were a party of 4 and there were 3 people working.  We felt like we were hanging out with our cousins just because everyone was really cool.  

We ordered the chicken sisigsilog.  When we placed our order, we were talking about ordering a side of lechon kawali.  The guy who was cooking was saying that if we did the combo, it was like $2 extra.  That was nice of him to tell us because when we got our food, it was actually a lot.  

The food was so good and we had great service.  Thank you for the wonderful experience.
author: Rachel L.

description: this place is so good! I walked by and it was super busy. I was solo so luckily I was able to slide in. I was on my way to get Mediterranean food. So glad I opted to check this place out instead!
author: Raquael J.

description: Food is below my expectation but the free soup is good. There's a lot of things that can be improve, like portion size. Service is good
author: Noel O.

description:
Be prepared to be thirsty for the next 12 hours after Tselogs...

Really wanted to try this place because there aren't very many filipino joints in the city. Opted for the chicken sisig and fried pork belly (special of the day). The chicken sisig was really good, it's great with lemon and I really liked it. The garlic rice was good; however, It wasn't warm... I saw that they scooped the rice and left it out until the other food finished cooking. 
Although this place was tasty, it left me super thirsty for the next 12 hours... I guess the flavorfulness was just the MSG T_T
author: Leilani Y.

description: Really liking this spot for some cheap eats. Have been twice now and I think that the pares silog is my favorite. On both visits staff have pushed a hard sell for the sissig which I tried this past time but found too oily and not as much flavor as some of the beef dishes. Definitely spend the extra $3.99 to get two entree choices.
author: Robin P.

description:
As a former Bay Area resident I've heard about the famous Tselogs in Daly City and had it on my list of restaurants to try. I regretted that I never got the opportunity to try it before I left. Several months before my most recent visit to SF in March 2016 I read an article about another Tselogs opening up in SF, situating itself in the space formerly occupied by Kare-Ken. The stars aligned this time and I was able to convince the No1DP to eat here for late breakfast.

CONCEPT: Filipino breakfast is collectively referred to in the native tongue as -silog. It consists of a meat, garlic fried rice (sinangag) and egg (itlog). It is most emphatically NOT a healthy breakfast and actually tastes best after a night of drinking. When I'm home for the weekend I can be waken up early by the smell of the garlic fried rice or if I'm asked to cooked the rice or egg for the -silog breakfast.

VENUE: The setting looked exactly the same as Kare-Ken: it's a TINY place somewhere in the Tenderloin. No1DP wouldn't feel too comfortable if I were to walk alone at night for a to-go dinner run. The place could probably seat 10 people max on the counters and twice that if they used the other side but that would be approaching being too crowded to the point of intruding other people's personal space. There's an open kitchen but even then that's tiny. It works when your brand calls for a small menu.

SERVICE: A little slow but this is to be expected on a Saturday morning. Turns out she was also doing double-duty serving out to-go orders.

While I was looking the menu I noticed that even being situated in SF the price of a -silog dish was less than $10. I was pleasantly surprised given that I expected SF prices to be high considering location but costs are similar to a -silog plate back in SD cities with a noticeable Filipino population. I'm glad that there are actually cheap yet GOOD options for dinner in the city.

- No1DP got the embutidosilog ($7.99). He got it because a lot of the meats were too heavy for him to eat as the first meal of the day and the description said "meatloaf". Turned out that said meat contained pork, which is a meat he typically avoids but he was able to still eat most of his dish. I don't like embutido all that much.

- I had my share of tapsilog, tosilog, longsilog, bangusilog and chicksilog from Filipino restaurants so I had their famous sizzling chicken sisigsilog ($8.99). Normal sisig is made with pork and the chicken variation was created as a healthier alternative. The sisig comes in its own cast-iron pan and is served sizzling. I could hear the chicken still being cooked as it was served. Some pieces of chicken were soft and tender and others that were exposed to the bottom of the pan were crispy. The lemon wedge makes a difference as it takes away from some of that fried aftertaste. Eggs were on the runny side (I usually like them less runny) and the No1DP and I observed that the rice cooled down rather quickly. Garlic fried rice is meant to be consumed hot.

As they were cooking I observed that the corned beef they use for their cornsilog was from the same company that my family buys when we make corned beef at home. Note that the corned beef is sourced from Australia and comes in a circular can, not the crappy American corned beef that comes in a square can. Though I can cook cornsilog, Filipino restaurants in SD do not serve cornsilog and I would like an option should I feel too lazy to cook.

I'm glad that I was able to cross off another restaurant off my ever-growing list of restaurants to try in the Bay Area. On my next visit I definitely would like to try their variation of one of the traditional -silog dishes.
author: Isabella B.

description: I was craving for Filipino breakfast and my old colleague mentioned that she's never tried it before. I decided to grab us a couple of Tocilog and added Tapa as well because I wanted to try both. I placed my order online and picked up the orders. I was really hungry so I ate mine there instead. The staff are friendly and even if it's literally a hole in the wall in the Tenderloin, it was clean. I thought both meats were a little too fatty for my liking. The garlic rice was decent and the portions were good. I'm gonna have to give it another shot in the future because I really thought it wasn't all that and I had high expectations after reading all of the great reviews.
author: Candice J.

description:
It's a small spot, with a very narrow, almost bar/counter-like seating. Don't let that fool you, though. The food is awesome! I know for a fact that the chicken sisig is really good, but I'm here to talk about the arroz caldo.

Came here with some friends around noon and the place was not necessarily packed, but that's because there aren't many seats to begin with. We had to face back to back, but had no problem talking to each other since we were still fairly close to each other. Service took a little long for my arroz caldo, so I did have to wait an extra tenish minutes but of course, the cooking times for different dishes will vary. I assume service was a little slower for me because my dish was being made with love, lol.

My friends got the chicken sisigsilog (Chicken Sisig Sizzling), which I was thinking I should have gotten since everyone seemed to be raving about it. But I was feeling a little under the weather and not at all hungry (I kinda just came for the company), so I decided to go with the arroz caldo because 1. It is one of my grandma's specialties and 2. I wanted something soupy and something easy to eat sounded appropriate for my state. 

I was definitely right when I said my arroz caldo was made with love! It tasted homemade just like my grandma made it. Everything about it tasted just like home! Everything from the taste of the the stuff to the added goods: toasted garlic bits, boiled egg, chopped green onion, the lemon to squeeze over the arroz caldo. The perfect ginger balance. Not too thinned out with water, just the right amount of thickness. It was definitely a bowl of home sweet home.

I also tried the chicken sisig, which was also really good. Great Filipino gem, for sure. A little piece of home away from home
author: Meghan J.

description:
I am very happy the owner of the first Tselog restaurant has opened a second location in city's Tenderloin neighborhood; a sectional part of the city that definitely need improvements other than riff-raff activities.

The second location is much smaller than the Daly City location with maybe a seating of twelve occupants. I was here close to closing time for dinner. I would imagine this tiny place would get crowded with a possible long wait at other times.

On my debut for dinner, I ordered the Corned beef-silog. For $8.99, I get shredded corned beef and over-easy eggs with a fat scoop of traditional garlic rice. From a guy with a big appetite, this popular dish is very hearty and filling. 

Since I was also drunk, I also ordered a side of lumpia. For $6.50, I get a dozen of these popular eggrolls with a sweet & sour dipping sauce, boss. Whether the sides were frozen or home-made, it was nothing too stunning. But I was drunk and I could care less and finished my meal. 

The Tenderloin has a huge Filipino community and not many Filipino restaurants and businesses. Tselog is welcoming addition to the neighborhood.
author: Matt G.

description: A small, hole in the wall keep it simple. Woman at the counter was friendly and helpful with menu selections. I order the recommended Sisigsilog and the pork belly special. Wasn't blown away by anything, but still enjoyed the experience. A nice lunch stop.
author: Moeketsi M.

description:
We can around 11pm and were told the sit in wait would be 1-2hours by a services guy at front door. So, instead, we made to go order. Waiting after waiting, at around 11:50, even people came after we came already got their to go orders, we still didn't see our food came out. At the same time, that front door guy just kept talking to random people without knowing that his customers have been waiting hours for only to go orders and their order tickets have been misplaced. So irresponsible!
However, guys in kitchen and pick up window are super productive and cute.
Such a huge contrast.
author: Choco S.

description: Got the special of the day which was pork belly. Came with garlic rice and an egg. Garlic rice is super garlicky and one of the best I've had in the city. Would definitely recommend!
author: Carol L.

description:
The food was REALLY good! The only thing I'd do differently is put less salt on the Sisig. It was good but too salty. 
The garlic rice was INCREDIBLE and the egg on top was perfect. It was over easy so if you dont like runny eggs I'd ask for them to cook it longer. 
The place was clean and small. No tables just counter space. Food was made to order which is perfect. The server/cook was courteous and attentive. I would definately go back.
author: Lisa M.

description: Philippines! Represent! Ordered sisiglog and tapsilog, both were good and very tasty. Feels like home. Great costumer service. It wasn't busy when we went. Right time to go is probably when they open.
author: Aizza A.

description: We tried this place based on proximity to our hotel and Yelp reviews.  It is simply awesome.  We had never had Filipino food, and were just blown away by the spice and flavor.  Service was super nice. In a city with so many great choices we choose to go back for a second time in three days.
author: Tim C.

description:
I have not, in recent memory, said the phrases "Oh wow...", "mmm!!", "SO GOOD!" as often as I just did during my lunch here. While the flavors are not complex, they absolutely embody those expected when eating COMFORT FOOD. That's the gist of what you will get here at Tselogs. I mean, come on, their logo is a fried egg! 

Get either the sweet marinated pork (Tocilog) or chicken sisig-sizzling (Sisigsilog) if you're feeling extra cold. Combined with the delicious garlic rice and fried egg, they will warm your body and soul.
author: Jason T.

description: i didn't think hole in the wall places existed in SF anymore but i was wrong. we stumbled upon tselogs and decided to try it out for dinner around 8 pm. there's a small eat in counter facing the kitchen which seats 8 and a taller counter against the back wall that seats the same. the staff was friendly and helpful in navigating the menu. the food was good but my meat was over cooked and dry. the dessert experience (coconut cream pie) more than made up for it. i'd recommend getting here earlier in the night - the staff seemed a little checked out this late in the night and they stop seating patrons at 9 pm.
author: Alexandra K.

description: The food is delicious and the service very friendly! The food is very close the Brazilian food, if you are Brazilian you will like to much!
author: Michel R.

description: Open kitchen where the chef prepared the food, but this place is really small. We ordered the tocilog which was good slightly sweet with garlic rice, but the chicken sisigsilog served on sizzling plate was way too salty for my liking. I barely touched the plate because it was just too salty it was kind of a torture to eat it.
author: Pam Ela Y.

description: The best buco pie! Crust is so flaky.  Buco filling not so sweet, and buco meat just soft and tender. Worth every bite. Tocilog was very tasty. Sisigsilog was so yummy. Service was great too.
author: Ry C.

description:
Loved coming here just for the simple fact that it was a hole in the wall. It kind of looked like a sushi bar but serving Filipino food. I got the Chicken while my bf got the pork belly and I swear Cali LOVESSS their garlic. We had garlic rice with it too. It was pretty yummy. Nothing crazy though. Next time I come back definitely want to try the corn beef. Someone next to me had it and I couldn't stop eyeing it. 

The service was great and it was very laid back with rotating amount of calm customers which was nice on our first night in San Fran. 

Would I recommend this place to my friends? Yesss!! Especially since its one of the rare places in Cali that's opened up late!
author: Yuena L.

description: Awesome Filipino food! The food is delicious and comes out fast, always tastes fresh. The staff gives great recommendations and the occasional sample item. Very accommodating and would highly recommend. Excellent prices, service. And food.
author: Ryan N.

description: We just arrived in San Francisco after almost 18 hours of travel. I was so happy to see a Filipino restaurant just around the corner from our hotel. My parents are Filipino immigrants so I grew up on this food. The pancit tasted just like my mom's and the longonisa felt like a slice of home. Really liked the vinegar, banana ketchup concoction the chef made and I wish there had been a bottle of it on the counter!
author: Chona C.

description: This place was cute and yummy! It's small but I really enjoyed it. Also, the guy in this pic has good music taste high for this - Ellie Goulding, wanderlust - snakehips remix, crave you - flight facilities hahaha noms; my tummy and ears are happy. I like the vibe of this place and its employees! The only thing is i feel like it's a bit pricey but it is SF. My bill came out to be $18 with tip & tax
author: Leslie L.

description:
Having lived in the Philippines for a few years I love the opportunity to find authentic places to eat here in the US.  San Francisco is one of the best places to find this and Tselogs hit the spot for me during my last trip. 

The menu is simple, but the food tasted just like what I use to eat while there in the Philippines.  The Lumpia was also fantastic. 

It's a smaller location with just a few seats but services was great and quick.  The place was packed while I was there and a few people came to pick-up to-go orders.    If you're looking for a great Filipino place, this is it.
author: Daniel C.

description:
Had the lechon and it was really good. It comes with garlic rice (super garlicky) and an egg on top, so there's a really good portion size.

Got it to go for lunch at the office and it was not a light meal :) The place itself was small, so it would be hard to come here with a group. Mostly seating at a bar, but nice to come grab some comfort food.
author: Michelle T.

description: Came here because Mensho had a long line as usual, and we were so hungry we couldn't wait. So glad we gave this place a try. It's the kind of hole in the wall- mom and pops shop that should have a longer line! Really yummy comfort food. I got the chicken sisig with garlic rice and fried egg. They recommend you place the fried egg on the sizzling plate and it was delicious! This place only seats maybe 10 people at a time and the owners were so nice. Good food for affordable prices, would definitely return!
author: Vivian D.

description: They closed early, wtf. We took a Lyft to get there too. Won't be back. All they said was sorry, we decided to close early today.
author: Mary N.

description: 100% recommend this place! It's small but the food is great! Ordered the Tocilog (sweet marinated pork) and Sisigsilog (sizzling chicken). Definitely will be going back for more!
author: Yolanda G.

description: We love the Chicken Mami, beef mami, I wish the Bangus size was a lot bigger considering the cost. Chorizo is good also
author: Kho L.

description: Picked up carryout for the chicken congee and sisigsilog. I liked the fact that this place was open late and had higher expectations based on the Yelp reviews. The garlic rice was hard and both chicken entrees were on the salty side. The congee was very salty to the point that it was not edible at all. Even my wife, who usually likes salty foods, could not handle it. Did you they drop a whole container of salt in that congee!?
author: Eric M.

description:
The lechon was sooooo good and the guys are awesome!! Super sweet to my older parents as well and very accommodating. 

My uncle got the chicken sisig and my cousin got the spaghetti...too much yummmmmyness in one!
author: Char C.

description: Wandered in here about 10:30 on a Thursday night and was so happy we did. Tiny little place with a cool soundtrack and super friendly staff. We ordered what was recommended to us as first-timers. I believe it was a combo of the Sisigsilog and we added fried chicken.  So. So. Yummy.  That's all I can say. Give it a try. You will not be disappointed!
author: Michelle W.

description: If I could give this place 6 stars, I would. It's a tiny place with very limited seating, so very easy to miss. We got the sisigsilog and Pancit Bihon. Would definitely come back for the sisigsilog multiple times in the future! The chicken was tender and juicy. Very flavorful without being overwhelming. Since, it is served in a skillet, the chicken was somewhat crunchy, which adds to the flavor overall. The Pancit Bihon was a curried noodles type dish and was good as well.
author: Mahak R.

description:
holy shit first of all: 

amazing service (s/o to Patrick and other amazing chefs) 

food is off the scale fucking gooood 

BEST filipino food i've EVER had hands down!!
author: Melina A.

description: I was like "wow" when I had my first spoon of their chicken sisig-sizzling! Great value, taste amazing, and serve food so fast, really love this small place :)
author: Erin H.

description: Dishes are really tasty and fresh, staff is nice, service is quick, portions are just the right size. The premises are a quite tiny so going with a group is not recommended, but with one other person or getting some food to go is a great experience!
author: James W.

description: Bomb Filipino food! Chicken Sisig and tapsilog sooo good. Gives good portions as well
author: Ella R.

description:
Okay, I'm going to be honest here. I really don't know what to expect from Filipino food.  Wanted to find something simple and close to the hotel we were staying in, so we came here based on the yelp reviews.  I ordered the Sisigsilog, which was recommended, and was not disappointed.  It was really flavorful and combined with the rice, it really did feel like comfort food.
Also, I LOVE the setup here.  It's a super small, hole in the wall type of place that just has a row of seating at the 'bar' and along the back wall.  We came before the lunch rush, but near the end, I noticed they were getting lots of to-go orders and people were starting to line up for pickup.  So, definitely not a great sit-down place for a group- but perfect for two during maybe odd hours :)
author: Gina F.

description: Filipino foods are really hard to resist, the smell itself is inviting, Tselogs is  a great place to go to when you are craving for Filipino food "silog". must try their food.
author: Anne G.

description:
Their sisigsilog just never disappointed you.

Used to go to their original location in Daly city, so happy that they opened a second location in downtown, just couple blocks away from home.

Location: 4* walkable distance from public transportation.  Pretty hard for parking.

Food:5* Nice presentation. Every plate has a sunny side up egg lays on the garlic rice. The sisigsilog is placed in the skillet to keep the warmth, tasted just perfect. Make sure to have it asap, otherwise will dry up.

Service: 5* All staff are really nice and proactive, they are willing to give you recommendations. I remember last time the girl gave us free icecream to try. They really make you feel valued.
author: Natasha L.

description: This place has legit and awesome food. I like that every one that works around here is very nice and good athmosphere. Only thing i am not a fan of is the space is too small and the music that they are playing seems like u are in a club but that is just because of the space other than that everything in this store is so good.
author: Rv Andrew V.

description: The food was super tasty, the service was friendly and fast. I got the pork and chicken combo and it was a TON of food. I definitely couldn't finish it all.  Plus I wanted to try their coconut pie. Get the coconut pie. Yum.
author: Rebecca I.

description:
Visiting from out of town, I'm not really big on eating at Filipino restaurants, I'm Filipino myself and a home cooked meal is not that far away for me.

It's a small spot but the staff is very friendly and the food was really good. They specialize on -silog dishes, my son and I were able to share a combo dish of Noksilog (fried chicken) and Sisigsilog (chicken). It was so good and finished the whole thing. 

My sister also ordered the Aroz Caldo which A's also delicious as well. Lumpia appetizer hit the spot as well because we came in hungry.

I'd definitely recommend this spot and come back again.
author: Lexie A.

description:
They're open late on Fri/Sat and quite close to bars/clubs, so they'll always be on the short list of druchies stops. I've tried the sisigsilong and the bangsilog, neither of which are that good. The rice in particular was quite under. Perhaps it was just an off night, or I wasn't intoxicated enough for my taste buds to enjoy Tselogs at 2:00am. It's late night comfort food, so it can't be all bad, but I'll try elsewhere before making a second stop. 

Also, be sure to double check what you pay for because according to one server/chef, their prices always change and not even the workers keep up. Better be safe that you're not accidentally overpaying.
author: Mo B.

description: Had a good experience at this small restaurant, which can fit about 10 people total. Service is great, food was simple and tasty, and inexpensive. All the silogs are served with garlic rice (wish it had a little more garlic though) and a sunny side up egg. Shared the chicken sisig and longsilog (pork), both were great. I definitely recommend the chicken sisig, which comes sizzling on a hot plate. All plates were at great prices, ranging from $5.99-$8.99. Had to share an order of lumpia of course, which comes with 12 for $4.99. Also had a piece of their coconut pie which I didn't care for as much as my friend did. Overall great casual dining spot in the TL, and I would come back. They don't serve alcohol here, but many great bars and pubs nearby =)
author: Will H.

description: If you're into people helping you eat some hot dang delicious Filipino food...boy do I have a place for you
author: Nick P.

description: Was craving Filipino food and was shocked how close this was to my hotel... great food
author: Lawrence A.

description:
Was recommended to come here by a fellow yelper I met at a yelp event last week!

This place was superb for comfort filipino food. Limited seating, so coming early. 

We ordered: 

SISIGSILOG (9/10)- sizzling sisig servied with garlic steamed rice, fried egg and some cucuber slices.  - It's everything you hoped it would be. Crispy, fatty and meaty all at the same time. Would have liked less salt in this and a little more balance in skin/fat to meat ratio. Other than that, this was ah-maz-zing. 

PARESILOG (5/10) - beef cubes infused with whole star anise pieces, served with the same sides as above. The sauce and flavors in the paresilog were tasty, but meat quality need to step up its game. Meat pieces were large, but meat quality needed improvement. Freshness wasn't quite there. Meat was chewy and dry and didn't taste like much without the sauce. 

BROTH: 9/10 - clear chicken broth for $1. Tasty, just want a touch more chicken essence in there. Perhaps a cup or two of less water will do the trick. 

Overall: 

Food: 7/10 -  from the average of the reviews above

Service: 5/5, friendly staff, informative on providing advice on the menu, even gave us small samples of meat to try before ordering. A homeless lady walked in and the servers diplomatically took care of her and ensuring the patrons were not interrupted. 

Atmosphere: 4/5 Cozy seating, open kitchen (I love watching food being cooked), ventilation system just needs to be turned up a notch as we left smelling like sizzling sisig from hair to shoes. 

Eat here.
author: Janice K.

description: Perfect late night place to eat or "the take a friend" to kind of place. I ordered the lumpia shanghai which I order in almost every Filipino restaurant, I give theirs a 4 out of 5 on it. However when I was here they forgot to cook my order so since they made me wait they gave me an extra order which definitely made up for it. Employees were smiling and nice. Oh and can't forget one of the best parts of the this place..... the music. Great choice of songs definitely helped me be on good mood even tho they forgot my order. At the end of the night I recommend this place to anyone around this part of the city.
author: Daniel L.

description: Authentic Filipino fare too delicious to miss when in the city, countertop seating transports diners to an Asian destination, creamiest chicken Sisilog dish - ever.  Must return...
author: Terrill C.

description:
Food: too salty, but like the crispiness of the fried chicken's skin.
Service: the guy at the front door with the sign up sheet is a total joke.
author: Yifan C.

description: Visited the City from Ohio where there's little options for Filipino cuisine so I took advantage of being in San Francisco's cultural food Mecca. We Walked in this downtown hole in the wall around 11pm on a Friday night and the place smelled like home. We ordered the lumpia, lechon, and longanisa plates. Food is great and and the guys working the line are so friendly!
author: Lynn L.

description: Simply put, two times in a row getting sick after eating at Tselogs, ordered the Noksilog is beyond coincidence.
author: R R.

description: They have rice porridge which was really good and actually reminded me of the Korean version, jook. So good when you feel a slight cold and want some comfort food. They also have two sizes if you want a smaller portion, which I appreciated! All in all, excellent music (throwback jams!) and solid food -- very Anthony Bourdain experience. I would come here again!
author: Alyssa M.

description:
If you're ever in the San Fran area, more particularly near-ish to the Shopping Area definitely take a walk to this place!  

I was craving some comfort food, and luckily this place showed up on my yelp feed!  If you've ever had Filipino food, one of the best breakfast meals or actually this meal can be eaten anytime time of the day is "Tapsilog" which breaks down to "Tapa" - beef steak with a fried egg and garlic rice.  So good! The beef marinade is on the sweeter side but I put some vinegar on it and it cut the sweetness but trust JUST as good!  My bf ordered the Sizzling chicken Sisig and THAT was freaking amazing.  The filipino Spaghetti is also another good one!  It's a sweeter sauce, cooked with hotdogs and topped with cheese.  Omg comfort food!!! 

This is definitely an awesome find and even if the place is small, I loved everything about it!
author: Lindsley A.

description: Average food, no better than a typical Filipino restaurant, but at least they're open late. Pleasant, fast service.
author: Inigo M.

description:
I love Filipino food so much and I love Tselogs so so much.  

Five stars for the food.  Amazingly good.  We got Sisiglsilog (Chicken Silog), Arroz Caldo Pares (Porridge w/ Beef), Palabok (Noodles) aannnnnd Lumpia!  

My boyfriend ordered the Sisigsilog, which was a good size portion with chicken, garlic rice cucumbers and tomatoes.  It was consumed really fast.  Nothing was left.  The porridge I ordered was piping hot and it was eaten slowly.  To make up the discrepancy between my order and his, we ordered Lumpia.  But I blinked and the Lumpia was gone.  I saved the Palabok for lunch tomorrow.  Really most of the food was so good.  Five Stars.  

Overall, I knocked off a star partially because this place is TINY!  Like really this is place is literally a hole in the wall.  It doesn't kill the ambiance though because the employees are charming and attentive and there's a nice vibe.  Although, I did get seated right next to the speakers, which I wasn't in love with, but I just "lucked out" in getting the one seat I'd dislike.  

I think I mostly knocked off a star because I wasn't in love with the Palabok, but all restaurants make their Palabok differently. Usually despite this, Palabok remains my favorite Filipino food, but I wasn't feeling the same happiness I usually feel when eating Palabok from this place. But everything else was so good, so my opinion remains unchanged that the food is still five stars!  

My recommendation would be, don't get the Palabok, get everything else.  Also!  We found out after we ordered, but supposedly, you can combine the silog options for the types of meat (like half and half I assume).  I just overheard that though, I hope I heard correctly, because next time I'm not going to hesitate to order a combo!
author: Cristina C.

description: Tselog's has a uniquely intimate and friendly, almost family-like environment that is hard to replicate. They generously created a dish for my dietary restrictions off-menu and I had the privilege of watching the chefs create it right in front of me. The music, the sticker fridge, the indescribable bursts of flavor from the freshly cooked meal all surmounted to an amazing Monday night evening. I will definitely be back.
author: Liz R.

description: Sooo good. Love the chicken sisigsilog. I want to try the egg pie next time :p very quick service and both times I've gone we didn't have to wait even though the restaurant is pretty small. Awesome to have the bar seating and the staff is very friendly.
author: Brianna N.

description: Small place with loud music.They give you a lot of food. It was good, but pretty heavy. I got the  sizzling chicken.
author: Ada M.

description:
WOW! this place is super good! we literally ate here everyday while visiting the city. they close hella late too which works out to our advantage! I even utilized postmate one time since we couldn't leave our hotel anymore.. thats how good it is.. LOL 

Portions were great! we basically tried everything in the menu except for the dessert. (cuz we didn't save room for it) but yea, so we got the sisig every time we ordered, it is just so good can't not not order it.. its chicken btw and they cook the egg so perfectly. also tried the daing na milkfish, it was fried to its crunchy goodness that we can enjoy eating the skin too. had the lumpia which let me tell you 6 is not enough..so order more! 

then we had all the classics like tapsilog, tocilog....ooohhh and the crispy pork belly aka lechon  kawali! they don't shy away from serving you that slab of pork! so please try that too! it appeared to be a cause of heart attack at some point of your life but the taste is well worth it!!
author: Charlyn S.

description: I tried the beef, it is too sweet for me and the sauce of the garlic is too strong. I did not end up finishing the whole thing. I feel the food flavor is too heavy while I always prefer the light flavor. The price is good.
author: Kelvin Y.

description: The food is good, but not authentic to the taste of home. Price does not match the way it tastes.
author: Mary L.

description: This is exactly the kind of place I love. The holiest of hole in the walls. I came for a late night meal, it was right around the block from my hotel. The place seats maybe 7-8 people. I had the beef marinated wth star anise, ginger and soy sauce. It was delicious. If I lived in or near SF I would come here a lot. Quick service, delicious food and relatively clean.
author: M S.

description: You guys... Seriously this place is amazing. Funky flavors, but they all work so well together. I was a little skeptical of banana ketchup, but it all makes so much sense! Just go for it and try everything that sounds unusual and you'll be super happy
author: Alexis O.

description: So value it's insane - went at 2am and was seated promptly, good service coupled with cheap eggs and bomb garlic rice makes this a no brainer 4 Star review for late night munchies / drunchies
author: Rohit G.

description:
This is a beautiful place. Comfort food at its finest. 

Service is chill and you can tell staff have a good time cooking for you.

Good portion size and really tasty after work/drinks.

Space is very small tho, so expect to wait a bit.

This place is also card friendly.

Cheers!
author: Lucas C.

description: Great little spot ! Excellent Food ! I had Lechon and Chicken Sisisilig. I'll be back again for sure. The staff here are all very friendly.
author: Keith B.

description: Everything was just perfect and it's yummy!  FYI the place can be confusing to find because it's a very tiny restaurant but it's worth it!!
author: Kathleen A.

description: What can I say that hasn't already been said? Great place for late night grub. This is a good spot to grab takeout from if you're staying nearby at one of the many hotels. I usually order an entree and an EXTRA order of rice with egg on top. It's so yummy!
author: Sherman K.

description: mmmmm d e l i c i o u s. This is my first time eating Filipino food and it left such a great impression on me. Came here for my bf and my first meal in SF. I ordered the sisigsilog and my bf ordered the tocilog, both of which were delicious! Every silog comes w garlic rice and 1 egg too. Left here feeling full and satisfied
author: Jenny H.

description: Always my late night request when I am out in the city. They close at 3:00 AM on the weekends. Filipino comfort food and done well. As the name suggest, they have a huge selection of tselogs which are breakfast meat, garlic fried rice, and fried egg. Choices of meat include tapa, longanisa, tocino, fried chicken, chicken sisig. and bangus! You bet, I am eating smoked fish at 3:00 AM.They have other menu items such as palabok, arroz caldo, and anise beef stew. It's counter top seating only which can seat about 6 people. Service has been great and I like listening to the sounds of tagalog going back and forth as they blast Zhu in the middle of the night. I have yet to try their house made pie!
author: Hazel F.

description: maybe I'm a victim of high expectations after choosing to eat here based on Yelp reviews, but I just wasn't that impressed with the food.  It wasn't bad by any means and the service was attentive - just didnt knock my socks off, chicken was a little crusty by sticking to the pan.  Much more preferred my meals at Tadu Ethopian, Mensho Tokyo SF, and Wonderful in Millbrae in my 4 dinners I had on my trip, Tselogs was my least favorite. If you're only in town for a day or two definitely try one of those instead.
author: Jeff F.

description:
Great place for Filipino food! The serving size is great and I really enjoy the laid back atmosphere with the chiefs cooking in front of you. 
I recommend the Sisig and lumpia! 
The convenience of it is great! Quick to get orders out the door!
author: Maggie A.

description:
Pros: Tocilog (Marinated pork, garlic rice, and fried egg) $7.99
Cons: Specializes primarily in "tapsilog"dishes so there aren't other Filipino food choices

I was at a conference at a nearby hotel and it's been awhile since I had Filipino food so I decided to check this place out. It's not the biggest space in the world, so I actually walked by it without noticing the first time around. Inside, there's some seats at the counter. Definitely more of a fast food joint.
