I ended up ordering the tocilog ($7.99). It comes with sweet marinated pork (ie. Tocino) with a scoop of garlic fried rice and a fried egg. Brings me back to breakfast back at my parent's house. Delicious.
author: Justin B.

description: Cozy comfort food. Be prepared to rub elbows with your seat mate. Enjoy Filipino food in the city nights.... or early early mornings which ever you prefer
author: Matthew G.

description:
Filipino comfort food!  I got the longsilog (longanisa with garlic rice and egg).  I completely devoured it.  The portions are just right, and for $10, it's definitely a deal.

There's no signage with the exception of their little sandwich board, so it can be easily missed.  And it's pretty small inside, but turnaround time is quick.

We wanted to try their halo halo pie, but unfortunately they ran out.
author: Vira P.

description: Super tasty! Amazing food, they treat you like family and great service. Can't wait to being more people over so they can enjoy the Lumpia and the pork.
author: Jay C.

description: I'm from Cerritos by way of Honolulu and know my  Filipino food. This little place is legit! Simple menu of the same dish done with ten or so different meat options. Nice people that seem to really enjoy what they do. If you haven't tried a silog or Filipino food before, just come in and ask for some tips. I'm sure they'd be happy to help. And my tip to you? Get the embutido. It's hard to find and made in house. Delicious!
author: Chas S.

description:
This place is the definition of "hole in the wall".  You can see the sign from the street.  It's almost bigger than the restaurant!  The seating area is at the counter, and the entire thing isn't much wider than the door.  The kitchen is facing the counter, and is perhaps even smaller than the dining area.  "Hole in the wall".

"selog" is usually spelled "silog", and refers to dishes served with egg.  A Filipino comfort food.  There are various options (tapsilog, etc), that indicate what the other dish is.  These folks serve it with a garlic rice.  There are other dishes available too, such as palabok.

Our party was Filipino (except for me), and they all loved it.  They loved the palabok, the arroz caldo, and the "selogs" they ordered.  I had a spiced beef "paresilog".  I think the main seasoning was star anise.  It was very tasty.  Prices were pretty reasonable for San Francisco.

A unique find with good Filipino cuisine.
author: Terry W.

description: So damn good! That's all I have to say. The flavors are amazing... I was seriously taken back at how delicious the food was. We had Chicken Sisig and Pancit and some ground pork, I forget what the pork dish was called, it was topped with an egg. Just eat here, you will not be disappointed.
author: Nichole V.

description: Awesome food!  Great staff, Mark and da gang are full of aloha & provide wonderful service!
author: Mr. W.

description: We enjoyed our adventure in SF and more when we found this hole in the wall Pinoy comfort food. Food is really great and price is reasonable. We would definitely go back and eat. My nephews from Norway had a blast with the Sisigsilog.
author: Manuel P.

description:
Stayed at downtown for vacation. Eat all types of food expect filipino food. So i checked on yelp if theres a near by filipino food so luckly i found stelogs

Ordered sissigsilog and lechon kawali with buko pie. Loved the food and will diff come back once i'm back in town.

Oh btw great services too.
author: Kirt V.

description:
The chicken sisig was amazing! The garlic rice and egg it came with hit all the right notes!

I will definitely go here again! Good portion, hearty meal and would highly recommend!
author: Billy S.

description: Awesome spot!! I was in the mood for a Filipino breakfast and had the tosilog. The dish was perfect. I'd definitely come back if I was ever back in town
author: Jamie C.

description: Hands down! Best tselogs ever. Food was amazing and consistent, the staff are very friendly and nice. Went there 12/30/17 midnight. Me and my friends really liked the food. Would come back for more.
author: Tiffany B.

description:
Oh my goodness! I am in love. After two flight cancelations and three layovers, this is exactly what I needed. I would have 8 layovers to eat this food. I've never had Filipino food before, and now I'm not sure if I can have Filipino food from any other restaurant because it won't be as good as this! I had the chicken sisigsilog, as recommended by Yelp and the restaurant. The presentation is lovely, the flavors are incomparable, and portion is perfect. 
This is one of those times I wish yelp had a 10 star option. One of the chefs convinced me to get the young coconut pie. I was pretty full from my meal but thought I'd give it a try. I wish the crust was more fresh, but the filling was good. Not too sweet and good flavor. All in all, the chicken sisigsilog is the way to go!
author: Gita B.

description: Really great place with really great garlic rice, and chicken sisig. Its a small counter only restaurant but serving very tasty food at a reasonable price. I haven't found a lot of good Filipino restaurants in the city but this is definitely one to try.
author: Ian C.

description: This place is is so good, its a little hole in the wall but this place shouldnt be unnoticed. Great service.
author: KillJoii X.

description:
Recommend: sisigsilog (chicken)! 

I had a great experience at Tselogs! The sisigsilog was delicious. The chicken came in a sizzling plate and on the side they had garlic rice, a lemon slice, and an egg fried sunny side up. (I tossed the egg into the sizzling plate to cook it more because I prefer my eggs over hard.) 

I would recommend you taste the chicken before adding juice from the lemon slice onto the chicken because the chicken is already seasoned with vinegar. So when I straight up added the lemon juice without tasting, my plate ended up tasting too sour. The chicken, egg, and garlic rice come together beautifully. The only drawback was that the chicken was extremely oily.

The lumpia (like an eggroll) was also delicious. They serve 12 pieces when you order the appetizer so I'd recommend you get it to share if you plan on ordering lumpia. My friend and I each ordered a sisigsilog and lumpia to share and could not finish our food.

Service is very good here. The waiters are friendly and your food is served quickly. I will definitely be coming back to try more.
author: Rica Z.

description: Super good !! I think it was lucky we didn't have to wait. A bit pricey because of the area. I ordered the combo with pork belly and chicken sisig!!!  Appitizer was lumpia for course. I would come back here anytime Im in the area.
author: Mike T.

description: Gotten take out lunch from here a couple times and its actually not that bad.  My usually type of food to eat when I get the munchies from alcohol though.  Maybe its just me but the food taste different sober, haha.  Still delicious! This is a small little spot and probably holds about 10-14 people inside or less.  Cool spot nearby my work so its a good walking distance for me.  Definitely will be back!
author: Ben Z.

description:
First time trying Filipino food and it blew me out of the bayyyyyyy. I am upset I haven't introduced this to my taste buds to this till this year but alas, I'll be back to the Tenderloin just for Tselogs!

We tried... 
- The Sisig ($10): I have nothing to compare this to but as my first time trying this dish, I found myself reaching for it throughout the night. This dish comes with garlic rice and an egg, with a side of chicken in a tiny pan. The chicken is shredded in form and coated in seasoning and some sort of creaminess to it. Spritzing lemon onto the chicken also makes you reach for the dish more as it can get a little too flavorful. 
- The Pork Belly Special ($12): This dish is one of my all time favorites among food in SF! I am a huge fan of pork belly and I let myself indulge when I ordered the special. Sitting at the long table facing the bumpin' chefs, I saw them deep fry these suckers and pull them out steaming hot to cut an entire strip per plate. The portions are large and the chunks of pork are huge as well! I honestly was in love with the crispy outside and the tender meat inside! I usually also try to avoid eating pure fat but was unable to escape the appeal of the pork belly here. It's incredible and I HIGHLY RECOMMEND IT. 

FYI - 
- Seating is limited here with around 12-15ish seats across 2 long tables
- Ask what the special is! I did, tried it, and was in love with the fried pork belly
- The carry out counter is essentially a window at the front of the store and is great! I'd highly recommend doing this as opposed to eating in for larger groups

TL;DR
Food - 5/5
Ambiance - 4/5
Service - 5/5
author: Sara S.

description: Egg rolls, yumm.  Very small place but worth the wait.
author: Kerry L.

description:
It's so nice to have a restaurant like this in downtown San Francisco! So needed: compared to the other restaurants in this neighborhood, this place is clean inside, inexpensive (without compromising the quality of food) and tasty. The folks inside are also friendly. Just remember that this is not a big place. They have a long counter that sits about eight people and another counter against the wall that could maybe hold four people. In other words, there are no tables. It seems like they cater more to take out, in which case you order outside through the window. But given my choices here in downtown San Francisco, I will definitely be back!

We ordered the chicken sigsig: very tasty, like shredded chicken adobo on a sizzling plate. I also ordered the buko (young coconut) pie. Not the sharpest tasting pie, but the fresh coconut tastes good.  There's the option to order this with vanilla ice cream, but that would only add to the monotony of colors. What they ought to do is offer ube ice cream instead as this would complement better the coconut pie.
author: Randy M.

description: My friend and I went there for dinner. I order the chicken dish my friend ordered the pork dish. The one with red color sauce. My friend through up 5 times that night, and we both had diarrhea and fever. We were both sick for a few days. Worst experience ever. If you want your health, DO NOT GO there.
author: Eva F.

description: I have been meaning to try this place and it definitely lived up to the hype! The food was very flavorful and hit the spot. We ordered lumpia, sisigsilog, and arroz caldo. The lumpia was served nice and hot, and did not disappoint. The sisigsilog was different from the normal traditional Filipino food offerings so we wanted to try it, and it was good, but would want to try a different meat next time - felt too healthy for Filipino food. ;) The arroz caldo was our favorite as it was packed with flavor and definitely had traditional Filipino flavors. We will definitely be back to try other dishes on the menu!
author: Roberta V.

description:
It's the places like these that make San Francisco and its food scene special. Great, unique and authentic food for a very reasonable price at a place that is open until 3am in the morning.

I tried the corned beef and the chicken silog so far and both of them were great.
author: Gokhan T.

description: A friend of mine brought me take out from this place. It's some of the best Filipino food I've ever had. I can't wait to try this place again :)
author: Laurina S.

description:
Found this little gem when exploring SF.
Place isnt fancy but they do have amazing Filipino comfort food. 

I am so sad that i didn't get to eat more of their menu.
The lumpias they have here are to die for!

I will definitely back on my next visit.
author: Anthony M.

description:
Tiny restaurant in the Tenderloin. There are maybe 10 seats, but each time I've been during weekday lunch hour, there has been plenty of seating. The restaurant is cute and clean, and since you're sitting at the 'bar', you get to see the cooking.

They specialize in silog, which is a meat paired with an egg and garlic fried rice. I had the Sisigsilog, which was chicken that came out in its own cast iron skillet. It's cooked with spices and onions, and it is especially great with the addition of some lemon and vinegar. You can even mix everything together and add some banana ketchup. By the way, the banana ketchup is worth a try! It's ketchup made completely with banana instead of tomato. The only thing I would love is if the rice were a little bit more cooked through with a stronger garlic taste, and the meat included some more veggies.

I've also had the bihon (rice vermicelli noodles with meat/veggies) and lumpia. Both were good choices as well. 

Most dishes are around $8.99. The portions are perfect for a meal, but not large enough for leftovers. Service is pretty quick, and they accept credit cards. They also gave us a coupon for 30% off our next visit.
author: Alice T.

description:
A Tselogs right off of Union Square!  My friend and I skipped the two hour wait at Mensho Ramen and walked right into Tselogs and did not regret our choice at all.  I'm familiar with the Daly City location thanks to obsessed coworkers and now it's so nice to have an option closer to home.  

Prices are definitely more expensive, but not horribly so: $5.99- $8.99 for one item and $2.99 extra for two items, which includes garlic rice and one sunny side up egg.  Two items left me plenty to take home.  None of this is exactly healthy (lots of meat, not a vegetable in sight) but the chicken sisigsilog is such comfort food and so delicious. 

The only negative is that the bar (the place is just one long bar and stools, facing the open kitchen) and glasses were really sticky with oil from the kitchen.
author: Joanne G.

description: Really good sisig. The tocino was well cured, not too sweet. The availability of condiments was great! Would come back when I'm next in town.
author: TK M.

description: This place is tiny with about less than 14 seats (they only have bar seating). The chefs take your orders directly, with a reasonable wait. We had chicken sisigsilog, lumpia shanghai (they come in a plate of 12 but they're really tiny), and arroz caldo. The food is delicious and filling (they are a bit oily but that's expected). According to my boyfriend, the lumpia shanghai is as good as the ones his Filipino grandma makes.
author: Laura L.

description:
Highly recommend trying their Sisigsilog ($8.99)! It's a chicken dish flavored with lemon and various spices, served sizzling hot in a skillet, and comes with a side of garlic rice and a sunny side up egg. The chicken was sooo well seasoned and bursting with flavor. Quantity felt kind of insufficient for me - I was satisfied but not full. From my experience at Filipino places, servings are usually quite big, but not here.

This is the 2nd location of Tselogs - the 1st is in Daly City, and it is the most popular Filipino place in Daly City. I'm never really in Daly City, so I was happy to hear that they've opened Tselogs #2 in such a convenient location near Powell!

Interior is very small - they only have a single bar with under 10 seats probably. This seems like the trend now with new restaurants in this area, probably because of increasing rents in the gentrifying Tenderloin neighborhood.
author: Jeffrey Z.

description: Delicious food with great service. Everything is made fresh. The employees all have great manners and are very polite.
author: Rebeka D.

description: I was looking for something delicious , affordable ... and this place was everything I was looking forward . Good vibes ... zero wait time... good comfort food and a great atmosphere !!! Recommend highly ! I'll be back!
author: David C.

description:
TLDR: place is small. It has only "bar" seating which has about 6 spots. Anyways good food, worth it to try, would come back! FYI this place is in the tenderloin. 

For an SF meal this is pretty well priced. every dish is $9 or under! Though how much food you get it is a dollar or two pricier than It should be imo. This place has been opened here for a few weeks now. This store replaced the curry+katsu place that used to be there.

All the silogs they have are served with garlic rice and an egg. I ordered the cornbisolog - the one with corned beef. The garlic rice is amazing. I have never had rice this good before. The egg is yokey and not bad. The corned beef was really flavorful and jist really tastes freshly cooked. My friend ordered the sisigsilog, which is the one with chicken and is apparently a favorite. The chicken came out on a frying skillet which is a nice touch! If you're hungry throw on an appetizer like lumpia from. Didn't try it this time around but I'll try it next time for sure! 

Would definitely come back again. They also gave us a 30% next order coupon. Which was also a nice touch!
author: Derrick C.

description: Needed a late night dinner after a show at the Orpheum Theatre and this definitely did not disappoint. I think we showed up at the exact right time because as we had our meal, the place got packed. It's not a big space and there aren't a lot of seats. We were a group of 4 and each ordered different things. My favorite was the chicken sisig. We also had the tocilog, paresilog, and the cornbisilog. We mistakenly ended up ordering lumpia twice, but we weren't mad about it. We did not have a problem finishing both plates. I imagine this place is a good representation of feel-good home-cooked Filipino food. The icing on top is the vibe you get from the guys working. Come in, take a seat, enjoy the music, and watch them cook you bomb food while they sing along to the music. Damn Filipinos and their natural talent. It's unfair, amirite?
author: Richelle T.

description: Got the Chicken Sizzling Silog and it was awesome! I haven't had many Filipino food experience but this is the best one out of them. The guys who worked there were extremely welcoming and friendly too. Would definitely recommend!
author: Natalie C.

description: Never a let down ! The chicken sisig and spamsalog is always hitting the spot! Can never go wrong with the garlic rice
author: Patrick Loon K.

description: Hole in the wall, probably seats 10 people at most. But it was sooo good. I enjoyed the Hawaiian music and watching the chefs cook. They got the food out fast and hot. Get the chicken dish! It's great. And don't ever forget to order lumpia if you're at a Filipino restaurant.
author: Stephanie G.

description: Very cute neighbor restaurant .  I love that you can watch them cook.  Meal was not local style cooking that I am used to.  The chicken was tasty however my garlic rice was a bit dry...maybe it's the type of rice they used.  I am used of having garlic rice made from Japanese rice.  They have a loyalty program.  Love supporting small businesses!
author: Stephanie C.

description: This is for their Jones location... I used to come here regularly for lunch to get my sisig fix. So sad and disappointed to find out today that they changed their hours to later in the day!
author: J.R. H.

description: Food was great! Ordered chicken sisig and the Palabok = YUM!! The staff was friendly and had a conversation with one of the cook about food trucks lol. You guys need to eat at this place. It is small but it feels like home. Thank you.
author: Carol N.

description: Wooooooow I can't tell you how good this is, environment is a little slow and the outside doesn't really sell you on how good this food really is
author: Robin H.

description: Drove 2 hrs to eat here!!! From sacramento everything is great and just how your mama made it! The garlic rice is great yo. Freaking bomb garlic rice & get the lechon
author: Valerie D.

description: The main things that are good here are the service and the food. The restaurant has severely limited seating, but works for the most part. In general, the service has been good (3.5), the food has been outstanding in flavor with the exception of a few dishes. Lechon and the Tselogs are great. I've only tried one of the specials and wasn't impressed. Price is excellent by San Francisco standards.
author: Adrian J.

description:
Came on a weekday for brunch so it wasn't too busy. Had the sisig tselog, palabok, and calamansi juice. The tselog and palabok were delicious, but a little on the salty side. Too bad the water cups were small and were not refilled. 

Pros:
Friendly and fast service
Reasonably priced

Con:
Parking is a little tough in this area

Tip:
Ask to sit in the front if you want brighter lighting, and the back if you want more privacy
author: Lola D.

description:
I was meeting one of my loves for lunch, and I suggested we come here. Neither of us knew much about Filipino food, so we didn't have a point of reference about what it was going to taste like.

We opted to have the chicken sisig, and an order of the eggrolls. The chicken dish was absolutely delicious!!!  I didn't eat the egg part, and gave it to my guy. The egg rolls...those were boring, and flavourless. We both ate just one, and shook our head, no. Waste of calories.

We went around 1pm, and there was seating. It's not a huge venue, and I left my walker outside, since there wasn't space inside the restaurant, really. A wheelchair could fit at the counter, but if you transfer to a seat, there won't be room for your chair, nearby.

The service was good, and laid back.  Also, this place is cheap. Since it's down the street from me, I'll be back!
author: Robin W.

description: Definitely hits the spot! Hole in the wall treasure. Fresh lumpias and everything is cooked after you order. Their pies looked good,but I wasn't able to try any since I ate too much and didn't leave room for desserts. I will be back to try the pies next time.
author: Jan Michel P.

description: good spot. the food here reminded me of my time living in Macau and enjoying Filipino food. the staff were all very kind as well. it is tough to run an operation that small, but they kept with the crowd to the best of their ability. the garlic rice was delicious and paired well with the meats. Sisigsilog was delicious. had a slice of buko pie as well that was extremely tasty. check it out!
author: Mal C.

description:
TSELOGS SECOND LOCATION! Tselogs Downtown area soft opening from January 26, 2016, from 11-2pm only for the next two weeks. Feb.8, 2016, open from 11am-9pm. 

I highly recommend their restaurant.  
They have passionate chefs, exceptional and attentive service, and affordable homemade food. They have captured the soul of Filipino food. Silogs come with savory garlic rice and an egg (will get a sunny side up egg unless you request). They have a different variety of meats to pick from chicken, beef, and pork. I recommend their Sisig (marinated fried chicken with special spices).
author: Denicka P.

description:
i have been frequenting this joint regularly for the past year but probably no more because:

1) they started a $15 minimum credit card purchase (i hate when companies do this)
2) they started charging 25 cents for a to go container for my food (if i had known earlier, i would have bought my tupperware)
3) they started charging 4% for healthy san francisco (they are a really small restaurant- i am surprised they have more than 20 employees. i mean, the space is so small that 20 people can't even fit in the restaurant)
4) for some reason, i am always short one lumpia in my 12 piece order

sadness
author: The Hangry Chef O.

description: I wish I went here a second time during our short trip!!   Haven't had palabok in foreverrrr.   Very good.  But the sisig was even better.    Slamminnn.
author: Rhobin D.

description: The ingredients are not very fresh, the food is way too sugary. Even thought the extra sugar masks the loss of freshness, it makes an unhealthy place to eat.  I'd choose other places to dine if I were you.
author: Alex S.

description:
Great value for money, and really friendly staff. 
The layout is like a sushi bar, so difficult to sit if you have a large group.
I had the sweet pork which was delicious, it comes with a serving of garlic rice and an egg. I wasn't so sure about the egg but it's actually really good.
Staff are kind, would defo recommend the place to my friends, especially if you're on a student budget!
author: Ruth P.

description:
Excellent food for the value.  Had the lumpia and lechong. Both were excellent!

Depending on the time of day, the Tendeloin part of the city can be sketchy, but that's the nature of being in San Francisco.
author: John I.

description: One of the best places in the city to get authentic Filipino food! Great location close to bars and they are open late, so good to get food after a night of drinking. Try to beat the rush hour because seating is limited, but also can take food to go.
author: Myleen R.

description:
Oh man.

The chicken sisig silog is what legends are made of. For real. Think about diced chicken in a creamy sauce that's also slightly crispy along some parts and just sizzling with friggin flavor. Oh yeah, and it's served on it's own cast iron skillet. 

Have that with/ without the egg mashed in it and your side of the fragrant garlic rice and it will feel WRONG.

But why would you want to be right??

Chicken Sisig, in the words of Ariana Grande, "You make me feel like a dangerous woman."
author: Jenelly D.

description: This place had the best home made lumpia in life, very authentic well because it is.  That's the only thing I have tried so far
author: Tiffany M.

description: First time here and it was delicious. We ordered the sisig and pork kawali. So good! I'd recommended both items. Both hot and fresh. I'll definitely be returning.
author: Kelsey Y.

description:
The food was perfectly filling for a reasonable price and was definitely tasty. I really appreciated the all around good vibes from the environment and the staff. 

If you're fed up with hour long lines, want a tasty and filling meal, but also want cozy feels then this is your stop!
author: Hannah M.

description: Great food. Different but tasty. Fast and pleasant service. A little small but a must do if you're in the area.
author: Bill L.

description: Checked it out with my friends while we were in SF. Really great food! Despite being a small store, it still very comfortable and inviting and the food was amazing! I ordered the popular sizzling chicken sisig and it did not disappoint!! I also ordered some calamansi juice and a side of lumpia to share to my friends. I wish I could've gotten more calamansi juice for the price since they only gave me a small canned beverage. The place is very nice and modern, the staff is very friendly, and I believe my non-Filipino friends who have never tried Filipino cuisine really enjoyed the food and the experience! Will definitely come back in the future!
author: Emilio C.

description: One of my favorite places to eat in any city in the US. Don't love the location so near the Tenderloin, but worth the adventure. Food done a simple and very very well. I always go for the combo with chicken sisig and longanisa. Sweet and tangy. Great combo.
author: chris c.

description:
If I could give Tselogs a 6 star on Yelp, I would. This restaurant is a definite go- to for authentic, no- frills, reasonably priced Filipino comfort food. 

They definitely have their "itlog" (egg) and "sinangang" (garlic fried rice) down, such that any "ulam" (meat dish in this case) that you order will likely be satisfying and scrumptious. I highly recommend the chicken sisigsilog. I have also tried the pares and tapas, which were also great.

I have ordered the arroz caldo once. As personal preference, I like arroz caldo when it's a day old and evaporated. Their arroz caldo is good for someone who likes the dish on the watery side.

The space is small, so I try to come during non- peak hours to avoid having to wait on the streets of the TL.
author: Pia D.

description:
Welp, now that Ive had Tselog's Cornbisilog, I am officially a changed man. I don't know what they did to the corned beef, but I'm almost positive they had help from some otherworldly source. 

To be honest, I was a little upset to see the curry place that was here before gone, but really, with these guys cranking out amazing grub like they do, I cant be mad!

To top off the deliciousness, the service was amazing! These guys are obviously invested in their business and take pride in serving awesome food. Keep it up guys, I'll be back!
author: Joseph F.

description: Not only inexpensive, but great tasting and friendly service too.  The place reminds me of Japan's restaurants with how small it is, but small also means more service as is the case here.  I've been here twice on a Saturday night and have not had a problem getting seated when it's been just a friend and me.  Kind of a hidden gem as it's really not that noticeable if you're walking by on the street.  This place is not suitable for large groups.  More than 3-4 people during peak times and you might have some trouble getting seats together.
author: Victor C.

description: Simply delicious. Went here late night on the recommendation of a new friend and it did not disappoint. Will definitely come back!
author: gina p.

description: The place is a pleasant spot in the TL with kind and generous owner and chefs. Food was good, but a bit too salty.
author: Denise N.

description: Is those hole in the wall type of places that have the best and most delicious foods, ever- Tselogs is no exception. I had the Paresilog and it was so yummy!
author: Nita C.

description: First time I had this type of food. We went for diner on a Friday night. Small place but very nice people. The food is awesome. Would definitely go again !
author: Vincent J.

description: Walking in the streets of downtown sanfo when we saw this. Was craving for filipino food. Service was excellent! Fried porkbelly was good.
author: Angel A.

description:
Perfect. Came here with my wife once we saw how close it was to our hotel. Full disclosure, we're half filipino and grew up on filipino cuisine, and eat it regularly, so we knew what to expect and were eager to see what SF had to offer. If your're not familiar with filipino food, it will be a new flavor for you.
Tselog did not disappoint. We had the chicken sisig, which was delicious. I don't eat pork, which is what sisig is usually cooked with, so this was the first time having it, and I couldn't stop eating it. I also had the bangsilog, which is a breakfast staple as close to home cooked filipino as it could be. My wife raved about the buko pie, and still tells me how good it was.
The only downside to this place is the limited seating and the crap neighborhood that it's in. The food, however, is the real deal.
author: Omar J.

description: Was in town for only a night and what better to get but Filipino food. Street parking was the way to go to get to this location. There were six of us and since it wasn't a busy time, there was space for us in the restaurant. The menu had a lot to offer, everything looks good. I ordered the sisig and lechon kawali. It was really good! Everyone else really liked their food too! The owners were really nice and had good music going! Definitely would come back!
author: Robert G.

description:
Tselogs was an unknown for my friends and I that visited on Friday.  Food is tasty, pricing is good, and the staff is very friendly.  Definitely worth checking it out!

Lunch plates are available with garlic rice, fried egg, and different meat options for  $8 or $9. 12 Lumpias are $6. They don't serve alcohol of any kind there, if you're looking for a beer with your lunch.  We definitely need to add Tselogs SF to our approved lunch vendor list that I'm putting together!
author: Leo C.

description:
Another rare place in the Tenderloin where the food is awesome.  I go there once a week for lunch during the weekday, (despite what my Dr says about my blood pressure).  The place is super teeny, which about 12 chairs, (6 along the open kitchen counter & 6 along the wall counter).  My routine is to call ahead, (they take about 20 mins).  

Despite my promise to myself I always end up getting 2 lunches, (& there portions are good to begin with--I gotta cut that out but I can't resist).  I get the spaghetti which has bits of chopped hot dog in a meat sauce covered with cheddar cheese and is super sweet.  THEN I get a tselog which has a big scoop of garlic rice, a medium-well egg and choice of meat, (the meats usually are also on the sweet side) & a slice of cucumber & a slice of tomato which I count as my vegetable for the meal.  They are always friendly with a smile.
author: Johnnie N.

description: Great food at a fair price. Small space but worth the wait for some very good flavor. When I ate there a lot of people ordered take out.
author: Edison H.

description: Hole in the wall without much seating but with some great food and friendly employees!
author: Anna A.

description:
Well, I had the spam. I love spam. That garlic rice is seriously good. I could just eat the garlic rice and an egg by itself. I really wish I knew how they made it.

It's a really cute welcoming kind of place.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
Came on a Saturday afternoon around 2:30 and luckily it was empty so the 2 of us got to sit right away! Within 5 mins the place got packed. Super efficient staff, only 3 people manning the whole operation! 

We had the chicken sisig sizzling plate and the sweet marinated pork plate and they were both 10/10. Amazing flavor, super tender meats. Perfect sunny side up eggs and the garlic rice was  

Would come back in a heart beat!
author: Jimmy H.

description:
Pros: SO delicious. Gonna be consuming so much more Filipino food now.... from here! And, lightning fast service

Cons: small place

A++ would drool everywhere again
author: B H.

description:
I love this place! I may start coming here quite regularly. Anna was really helpful with the menu, and was attentive. She suggested I get the chicken sisigsilog as a great introductory item of the establishment, and it came with an over easy egg and some really stellar garlic rice! I, of course, mixed this all together. I also ordered some chicken soup broth and some killer pork egg rolls.

They also have self service coffee, which is really nice for days I want to start with a good meal and caffeinated without having to wonder if the server realizes I'm a coffee addict. 

I also always love to see a place where you eat at a counter with them cooking right in front of you. It's refreshing  to know that the food will be stellar.

I will most certainly add this to the list of good, easy food places in the area. I was shocked at how affordable it was as everything I got came out to less than $20. Really good value!
author: Zachary T.

description:
This place is a small little corner shop. Kinda reminds me of an authentic ramen shop. 2 bar like tables on both sides and stools to sit. You can watch the workers cook and prepare the food. 
The prices are fair and the amount they give you is satisfying for your stomach. Overall the workers are friendly and attentive to your needs. The food is great. I got the Tocilog. The pork was tender and sweet. The garlic rice is fresh and tastes great. I do recommend coming here.
author: Julian G.

description:
Took care of me right when I walked in. Service was good from start to finish. 

The Sisigsilog was LEGIT. Came on hot plate with rice and egg on a separate dish. Really simple and really good.

Overall great little hole in the wall. Would absolutely go back and can imagine this being my go to after a night out.
author: Drew D.

description:
Best Tapsilog, tocilog, and lumpia in the City.  No need to look elsewhere.  The service is also terrific, with some very humble and friendly folks.  

The thing to watch out for is that this place is TINY.  It can be a real line here.  

But things are reasonably priced, and the food is very good.  So it is really worth the wait.   But tip well yeah?  They are good people here.
author: Mark M.

description: Food was great, and the staff were extremely friendly and helpful. Only real issue is that place is very small. Would not be good for a large group of people.
author: James S.

description: The place was quite small, so it was best to get a to-go. We ordered the Sisig, which has a recommended sign on the menu. It was a bit of a wait, but food tasted delicious. Totally recommend it!
author: Winny F.

description:
been wanting to try this place for almost a year and finally tried it!

ordered the chicken sisig annd lumpias

lumpias were okay, but it didnt really taste like pork. wished there were more options for the sauce tho

the chicken sisig is super filling but i feel like its not that special
author: Amy L.

description:
Was just about to sit at the counter when an ENORMOUS COCKROACH wandered across it.  The cook casually reached down with a napkin, squished it, and removed it. Which was very courteous, but... 

Looks like a tasty place! But... wow... that was a scary bug.
author: Anna D.

description: This place was great. Service was amazing, they were very attentive to their guest. The lumpia was so good. We had 9 pieces thinking that 12 was too much, we were wrong it went down sooo good. The garlic rice was perfection, not to "garlicy" just had the right flavor. We had the fried chicken which was cooked nice and brown. The Tocino just had the write flavors, not too sweet. The longanisa was excellent as well. Must come and try it out open late which was the best!
author: Karl V.

description: We ordered the tocilog and sisigsilog, came with rice and an egg. MASARAP!!! We thought the portions were gonna be too small but they rlly hit the spot. The ambience of this cute little restaurant was very nice as well and the servers are hella nice. Will definitely come back next time I'm in the city, thank you!!
author: Micaela B.

description: Great meal!  My wife and I were visiting SF with mom and found Tselogs thanks to Yelp.  Very small (seating for ~12) but quick and great food.  Mom isn't an adventurous eater but loved it too.  Had pork egg rolls, chicken sisig (GREAT) and beef.  All were great, as was the rice...
author: Bob K.

description: Yummmy . Love good SF quick Filipino grub :) . So happy ! It's a hole in the wall, but so worth finding! The customer service is friendly, but the food might take a while on the night time, so order ahead of time. Overall, delicious!
author: Kenneth S.

description: This place was great!  Lots of delicious food for very little money, nice staff, cute little place.  Very small and probably more of a takeout place than a sit down, but there are a few spots. If you're looking for a cheap, quick, and delicious dinner before going out, check it out.
author: Russell W.

description:
Honestly, this is the best fucking Filipino food. Came here after partying & it was the most amazing comfort food that reminded me of Lola's cooking. 

I highly recommend the Chicken Sisig with garlic rice. I would definitely come back here again. And again. And again.
author: Sabrina W.

description: Never had good Filipino food besides friends' family parties until I came here. Like the pub atmosphere and a great place to have a few beers with some dank Filipino grindz.
author: Sang Yoon K.

description: Took my in-home support worker out for a quick bite since it is the holiday season.  Decided to try Tselogs SF since it was in the TL (my hood) and because my worker is Filipina.  It surprised me cause it was a counter style diner with Japanese style wooden stools for seats.  Me and my worker shared a plate of lumpia and then she ordered something, and I ordered the braised beef with gravy with rice and a fried egg on top of the rice.  It was a quick snack cause my butt was hurting from those tiny wooden seats   The food was delicious and it was quick (once I let them know I wanted 'quick').  I felt like I was on some side street of seedy Manila since the location is TL, but felt right at home.
author: Tamara C.

description:
This review is after multiple visits because I'm a good reviewer. 

Damn, this place is cheap. I work in restaurants  (another reason I'm a better reviewer than you), and I 'get' why things have to be so expensive here. It sucks because I'm not rich, but I understand. That being said, I don't get how this place makes money with nothing being over 8.99. Whatev, works for me.

The chicken sissig is so damn good! Think hot sizzling chicken 'carnitas'. Beef stew is also good. I thought the lumpia was also good and prefered it had minimal filling. Buka pie was delicious to me. 

Most dishes are served with a good amount of garlic rice and a fried egg.  Food comes out quickly  (when I've  been there)
author: Dash_Rendar _.

description: So good and super comforting. Who knew that there was actually good Filipino food in SF?! I'm used to my usual go-to spots in Daly City so finding out about this place was great. The Sisigsilog was yummy and didn't disappoint. The staff is friendly and it was a lot of fun watching them work.
author: Tiffany I.

description: Tselogs says they are trying to bring Filipino comfort food to America.  I'd never tried it before, so a friend and I gave it a shot-- amazing!  I definitely want to go back and try more things on the menu.  Small and very friendly place.  My friend got the chicken, and I'd definitely go for that again.  Also, big fan of the fact that you get a couple fried eggs on everything.  "Breakfast" food on a dinner item is always a win in my book.
author: Ryan H.

description: AMAZING food and AMAZING service. Not a lot of room so not suitable for a big family or group
author: Marina D.

description: Everything is amazing here! The food, the service ... it's all great. We had the tocilog and the hot dog silog, and were lucky enough to visit during one of the select times they serve chicken adobo. It was all very tasty and served promptly. For dessert, we had the mouth-watering ube pie a la mode. I'll definitely be coming back!
author: Jona H.

description: Cornbisilog was delicious. It's 5 stars mostly because the service was outstanding. Not much seating, but cozy.
author: Dickin M.

description: I enjoyed their laid back 90's hoppin' environment very much! The service was adequate for a bar type service. The whole restaurant seats only 10! We came at an odd hour at 5pm so they had ample space and the food came pretty quickly. My husband and I followed the waitress's recommendation for the most popular dish. I was not impressed with my chicken sizzler platter due to lack of flavor and it was quite greasy. But the chicken broth soup was surprisedly very tasteful. My husbands BBQ pork was pleasant. Overall - it was a fun visit because we got to sing and chair dance our way thru our meal! Otherwise, the food wasn't anything we would return for.
author: Staci L.

description: This is my second time having Filipino and I was impressed by their chicken sisig sizzling with garlic rice and an egg. My it was so good! I would definitely recommend it. I tried making that dish again that night but it just wasnt the same. I just wanted to keep on eating more. The set up of this place is unique. I think it is awesome that the guest get to sit in front of the kitchen and see our food being made. The place is small but luckily I made it after the huge lunch rush. I definitely want to try their other dishes like the hot dog or lumpia.
author: Peter N.

description:
I love coming here. It's clean and cozy, and I can sit at the counter reading, watching the cooks, and listening to the light chatter in Tagalog among patrons and servers and owners. Friendly people of all colors flow in for elegant, homey meals on the cheap, eating in or taking out. It's got the best kind of neighborhood vibe -- though I live in the Mission, I come over here and feel the love and comfort food lift up the neighborhood. And that's not always easy to do in the Tenderloin. 

If you're new to Filipino "silog," a silog is a meal that includes a protein, garlic rice, and a gooey, fried egg. Tselogs serves several different kinds, from fish to chicken to sausage, prepared with Filipino flavors. Sisig-style (chopped up pork or other meat cooked on a very hot cast-iron pan) is the most popular and most loved (ask Anthony Bourdain).

This place is a tiny shotgun-style diner with updated blond wood trim, tucked away in a dive-y area north of Market, though the restaurant inside doesn't feel dive-y at all. Sitting inside, I feel like I'm in the Lower East Side of Manhattan, or tucked away somewhere in a Manila enclave, or in some quiet tiny gem in a big Asian city. 

Today the special was chicken adobosilog, but I always get my favorite, the chicken sisigsilog, because I love sisig, and the fact that it's chicken makes it feel a little healthier than the original pork version. You'll still feel heavier after eating it though, but the garlic rice mixed with the yolk-y egg, and the crispy bits of chicken from the bottom of the sizzling single-serve cast-iron pan -- worth it. When you get the sisig, wait a few minutes so that the pan can create the crispy charred bits of chicken on the bottom, then mix it around, drop your egg on top of your perfect garlic rice dome, smoosh it down, and then scoop the chicken bits on top. (Alternately, you can drop the egg on top of the sisig/protein and then mix that with the rice.) It's as satisfying as the crispy rice bits at the bottom of the stone bowl in dolsot bibimbap.

I just wish they had Turon for dessert! That and mango shakes. This is friendly, affordable Filipino comfort food at its best.
author: Robin L.

description: I'd rather go to AJ's by balboa honestly. This place wasn't my cup of tea. However.. good prices, friendly staff, maybe I'll give it another go sometime.
author: William B.

description: If you are Pinoy and need a taste of home.. this place is legit! Try the chicken sisig :)
author: Deizel S.

description: I almost wanted to give it a 3 but I recognize the potential of this place. First, the owners and chefs clearly have a system that enables to produce the same quality and expectations for each of their menu items. Their menu is limited so they can try and do the best for each dish. The presentation is excellent and all the components match and complement but also show Filipino inspiration and tradition (garlic rice and egg!). Just a little critique: the lechon kawali can have crispier skin but the meat was not overcooked and was still very tender and moist. The lumpia shanghai needed a little more kick such as perhaps shrimp or salt and the wrapper wasn't as crunchy as it could be but again I could see how careful they were not to overcook it so clearly care is given. I wasn't too keen on the chicken sisig since I'm more used to pork sisig and it had an almost adobo taste to it. However I noticed many of the Indian patrons loved the chicken sisig so I get it. The buko pie needed more sugar as some people don't eat it with ice cream. Overall a very pleasant experience.
author: Mr W.

description: Came here for lunch on a weekday. The place reminded me of eating in similar fit outs in Japan. You can see the food being prepared, it's cozy but the space works.  The guy who took care of us, I think his name was James was really chill. He took the time to answer our questions and when he didn't know himself, he asked the chef. He was forth coming with the suggestions and let us try somethings before we made up our minds. Heck even after we ordered he brought some stuff out to say hey try this. We didn't look special but he made me feel like I was. You get garlic fried rice and a fried egg sunny side up. The flavours are there. It's no Michelin star, you get what you paid for and then some. I thought it was value for money. I had Carl's Jnr for about 9 bucks and would have loved tobhave gone here instead if they were open at 2am but it is what it is.
author: Franky M.

description:
Amazing food.  I had the lechon kawali.  The pork belly was so flavorful.  The egg had to the 
texture of the already excellent garlic rice.

This restaurant is a small hidden gem.

Prices are also excellent.  5 stars.
author: Michael M.

description: Get the sizzling sisigsilog, squeeze lemon, pour sriracha, and eat with the fried egg and garlic rice. Tasty!
author: Kamron W.

description: Really good post-dancing/night out meal! I had the chicken sisig and it was amazing! A great take on the traditional sisig (usually made of pork). The dish was seasoned perfectly and the rice was a great complement to the meal. I wasn't able to try anything else on the menu, unfortunately, but I would definitely come back the next time I'm in San Francisco.
author: John Patrick C.

description: Delicious Filipino comfort food!  Friendly staff, prompt service, simple menu, and very filling.  Trust me, you want to eat here.  Seating is very limited as the place is very small so try to beat the crowd.
author: Chris B.

description:
I haven't tried their other location in Daly City, but I've heard from my other friends that it's really good, so once they opened up in the Tenderloin, I took the opportunity to go there. 

So, I came in here with my friends a few nights ago to try it out. As other people have previously mentioned, it's a hole in the wall -- and that's pretty cool. Makes you feel super cool when you stumble upon it. I guess you can call it a hidden gem in the Tenderloin. The only seating they have there are the seats that line up along the counter, and another row of seats that run parallel but face the wall.

One star off because the workers weren't that friendly. Maybe they were having an off day, who knows. My friend complained that they kept staring at her, which made her feel very uncomfortable. 

Another star off because of the food. Some of my favorite Filipino foods are tocino and lumpia. So naturally, I ordered the tocilog and a plate of lumpia to share with my friends. The meat for the tocino was sweet (as it should be), but lacked flavor. The meat was also a little too tough, so that was weird to me. The lumpia tasted alright, but I've had better lumpia from other places. 

My friend thought his longsilog tasted decent. I didn't try his plate. On the other hand, I tried my other friend's plate. She got the chicken sisigsilog. She thought it was a little too salty for, but I disagree. I thought it was a perfect balance of flavor and saltiness. I also was amazed at how it was served on a sizzling plate- I haven't seen that before. Therefore, if you do plan on coming here, I recommend the chicken sisigsilog!
author: Rachel M.

description: This review is based on location and food. F*ck this location on Jones street in the heart of the Tenderloin. The food sucked. One of the line cooks added too much salt on the rice. It gave me a headache and to top it off they forgot to add the pork grinds and green onion to my chicken Sisig like they do in Daly City. I'm disappointed at this location. I told the waiter I had some family from Southern California that had never ever had chicken sisig. What a disappointment. Tselogs SF, garbage!! The best location is in Daly City.
author: Brian B.

description: Nice cozy place, Japanese style setup and seating.  The food is good, although I couldn't tell you if authentic. The workers here are chill and welcoming; helpful if you ask and are willing to customize a bit.    Definitely recommend this place, Will be back next time I'm in town
author: Rish P.

description: Found this gem while looking for places to eat close to work and I was surprised, the place is tiny but the food is amazing, tried their famous chicken sisig as suggested by everyone, it was delicious and you can't beat the price and their portion.
author: Vanessa J.

description: What earned the 4 stars was the feel of the place, tiny hole in the wall where you sit at a bar facing the kitchen, where you can talk to the cook as he prepares your food; reminiscent of eating in Japan.  Food was good, but I really like fried spam.  Sizzling chicken was awesome!
author: Corey A.

description:
Cried tears of equal parts joy and homesickness, eating food from here.  

Everything about it is just like you'd find in Manila: from the variety of rice used, to the way the egg is fried, to the seasonings in the lumpia.  Seems like simple fare, but if there's a nostalgic place in your heart for Filipino breakfast plates, come here.

If my auto insurance adjuster knew how much I'm about to frequent the TL, (s)he'd probably raise my premium.
author: Nicole L.

description: Food is GREAT. Service is QUICK. Price is surprisingly AFFORDABLE for a restaurant in the city. Best Filipino food for me  They're open until 12mn on weekends which is cool
author: Maxine G.

description: Small place but great and friendly staff for any questions even if you can't pronounce the name of the restaurant. Cheap delicious food is great in the city where everything is expensive. The Sisig and Lechon are delicious definitely recommend while in SF.
author: Jeff R.

description: Goodha!!! I'm craving for some back homemade taste, I let Yelp do the search and oyeahhh I got the taste that I'm liking for, first of is the corned beef silog and the tapsilog... Followed by Palabok...that trio and the Tapsilog all 3 captured the taste that I am looking for. I will recommend this place to my friends who visit the SF Tenderloin surroundings in the heart of Union Square.
author: Rey D.

description: Since my mom lives less than two blocks away, we always order take out. The chicken sisig is very good. The beef was out-of-this-world weird and felt like I was chewing wet cardboard. The palabok only had a dribble of sauce and was almost all noodle. The ube macapuno pie tasted several days old (or defrosted from frozen) which I definitely will not order again. The guys working here are so nice and friendly!
author: Eliz Y.

description: The food was great. Tasted fresh. Great service. Location is small but you get a good San Francisco experience. Strongly recommend. I stopped by, by accident.
author: Mario C.

description: This place is a hidden gem in the Tenderloin. Casual counter service, delicious food and fast, friendly service. Highly recommend the Sisigsilog and the Young coconut pie for dessert. Check it out!
author: Gwyneth J.

description: This place is the bomb. Food and staff are exceptional. Really care about their customers. Will come back for sure.
author: Christopher F.

description:
Congratulations on the 2nd location! You guys already know this one is gonna do great downtown!! 

Best chicken sisig in the area (as you can see from all the pics/videos). If it's your 1st time, dine in, and get the chicken sisig. Everything i ever ate here was hella good, and I do mean EVERYTHING.

I think the most underrated thing on the menu is the spaghetti! It is of course Filipino style, hot dogs, sweet sauce, & hella cheesy. All the tselog plates are the shit. The arroz caldo is not bad, perfect if your getting tired of the breakfast plates. The lumpia is lumpia, always good. Chase everything with a side of sabow, seriously it will make your day. 

I love Tselogs. The bay needs more Filipino places that have good food & stay open LATE!
author: Mono L.

description: Had the chicken Sisisilog and marinated pork. Both delicious with fast and friendly service. Come now to get a 30%off discount card!
author: Jiajia C.

description: My husband and I were in SF for the weekend and were looking for late night places to eat near our hotel (Scarlet Huntington). Less than a mile a way we found this jewel. Very friendly employees and the food was so delicious, we ended up going a second time, because I could not get the sisigsilog out of my head! The first night we went, we didn't wait very long to get seated, but the second night it was about a 30 min wait. There isn't much seating and because it's close to many bars I would imagine the wait is much longer once the bars start closing. The good news it is open until 3 am.
author: Nina T.

description:
I was so excited when I walked past this spot a month a ago and saw that it was a new Filipino restaurant in the neighborhood! I've been looking forward to going ever since I passed by the place. Today, I finally was able to try it out. 

The spot is very small. They have a bar area for you to sit and eat. The service is very good! The workers were all very attentive and friendly. I ordered the tocilog, my friend had the chicken sisig-sizzling, and we both shared the lumpia. The dishes were all a good size, accompanied with a side of garlic rice and a fried egg. We had a hard time finishing everything. The food was flavorful, hearty, comforting, and did not disappoint. Everything I wanted out of the trip. 

I'll definitely be back. I hope Tselogs SF gets great business here in the TL.
author: Sarah B.

description:
Ate here yesterday...it was fantastic!
Great food, great service, 2 thumbs way up, I'll certainly be back again and again, with friends.
author: Samuel J.

description: Had sweet sausage. Good combo, delicious. Fast and friendly service. Small and cozy. Very warm.
author: Stephen C.

description: The was my first venture into Filipino food, and it didn't disappoint. The garlic rice is bomb, and the chicken special is so rich in flavor. The set up is a very narrow hole in the wall, so not a great place for  groups (or really more than 2 people). But definitely a place to bring your S.O./major foodie in your life. Highly recommended culinary experience.
author: Kate P.

description: Found this place on yelp. I was hungry and waiting for my papers at the Embassy. Just like in any culture, I can eat bfast food all day! That's what Tselogs main theme is; they do serve non bfast items. I had the long-si-log. Loved it...solely because it's how one would make it at home! Plain and simple. Can't beat the price either!
author: Florian C.

description: The food is amazing. The service is horrible. The girl told us to sit at the counter, slammed some water down, and silently left a pile of utensils to the side. Not a word after the initial "here or to go?" conversation. There was one really nice guy who took our order, cooked our food, prepared our dessert, basically everything except for seating us and taking our money. It's quite a shame because if I lived in SF, I would get take out all the time. If you are dining in, don't.
author: Tracy S.

description: This place is extremely small. With that being said, I had the pancit bihon and I appreciated that they had a vegetarian version of it, quite good. The service was good too.  We also didn't have to wait that long.
author: a f.

description: Very good food but yes this place is really small, really! But good peeps and again good was delicious!
author: Tasha D.

description: The food is great and is like comfort food for me since it's rare to come across Filipino food in SF. The place is small and I think they could expand if they wanted to! Definitely not as good as mom's filipino food but the service was great and I'd probably come back again.
author: Katrina P.

description: Chicken sisig all the way! Never thought it would compare to the authentic pork version, but now I prefer this! Awesome bar set up for an intimate experience.
author: Maurice G.

description: This is among the best food I've had, and I've had a lot.  New to Filipino cuisine.  Favorites were the Paredes(?) beef and the purple yam pie.
author: David S.

description: Best phillipino food ever!! The longganisa with garlic rice was delicious and I'm definitely coming back. Service was great as well!
author: Solomon J.

description: One of my Favorite silogs is tapsilog and this place serves the best Tapsilog, I really love it!
author: Mae Perez L.

description:
This is not the same as the original Tselogs in Daly City! The original had the most creamiest, delicious sizzling sisig!! I've also tried the temporary location which is at a bar, and that place made the sisig with too much onion and was not even served on a sizzling platter, which is kind of the point of ordering sizzling sisig. I thought all locations would be the same as the original, but they aren't. Not too sure if I'd even spend the time and money at the newest location at Colma because of expected disappointment after trying out these other locations. Has the management  or ingredients changed? Regardless, it's just become more of a disappointment. Also, a little too expensive for not best quality of food.
For 2 people, our total was $27:
1 sisig/sisig combo
1 sisig tselog with an extra egg
author: Jay A.

description: Happy that I get to try tselogs the first time! I have heard a lot about it and wanted to try it but never got to the daly city branch. I'm glad that they opened a branch here in downtown SF. We went there for lunch yesterday. Although the place is a bit small, they serve good food and brought a lot of nostalgia! Tender and flavorful tapsilog and tocilog, served with garlic rice,though the egg can be a bit bigger. Clean place despite being in the tenderloin. Staff are nice and friendly! Overall it was A good experience and will surely come back again.
author: Robyn P.

description: We were just here last night. After strolling around downtown.. looking for a late night grub and saw that tselogs was still open but closing in 20mins so went as fast as we can. Patrick, the guy who took our orders was such a great guy. We were all just having fun and lively at 3am and he was going along with it. Food was great.. but the guy who was cooking was a little off, seemed annoyed glaring at us. well.. I understand where he's coming from.. so close to closing and got bunch of orders the last minute.. HEY MISTER.. You have to be a little bit nicer and patient.. you work with customer service as well. That is my only complain. But thank you still for cooking. Next time.. pls be nicer.
author: Caye L.

description: It was my first time at this place and I fell in loved with it after tasting their tasty food. I had the Sisigsilog and my friend got the tapasilog. We both tasted each others food and we both liked it very much. I have not have this type of food in a very long time which probably was when I left philippines 10 years ago. It's a small place to eat at but food is very good. Staffs are very friendly, clean place, and nice vibe when you walk in. I will definitely be back here again.  SALAMAT for the good meal!
author: Jofferlyn P.

description: Worst food. The tapa was so tough. The milkfish had bones. This place is located in the roughest part of San Francisco surrounded by homeless and poverty and crimes! Pls beware
author: Leslie M.

description: tselogs nice filpino late night eat open till 3am on fridays and saturday food was really tasty and flavorful great after having a few drinks at the bar the lachon crispy pork belly and lumpia egg roll and the fried chicken was really tasty will go back again for sure when i am in sf for some late night eating !! check them out tselogs  good eats yelp on yelper
author: sushiatown s.

description: I will defiantly be coming back here food was great I had the marinated pork which came with alot of meat if you want to get your moneys worth.
author: Vincent G.

description: The only downside to this place is that it isn't next door to my house. It's so good I ate dinner there last night and I can still remember it. Service is great. Food is amazing. The inside is small but that wouldn't stop me from getting it to go or waiting.
author: Nia S.

description: This probably the grossest food I ever tasted. Went here last weekend and ordered some beef with eggs... service was very poor, had to wait for almost 30 minutes, then finally food came out fuckin' dry and eggs were burnt. The space is too small to move around and the smell of body odors from customers are just way too disgusting to bear. Not sure what kind of people eat here but it's definitely not up to my par. bleh.
author: Jay B.

description:
got a craving for lumpia, and found this spot on yelp. lucky for me it was only 4 blocks from the office! its a little hole in the wall that you will miss unless you know what youre looking for. everyone was friendly, and the food came out quick. i got the shangsilog, which is a bunch of lumpia, garlic rice, and a fried egg for $8. not bad. my lunch routine gets boring quickly, so adding this place to the roster will be great.

I LOVE LUMPIA!!
author: Gionni B.

description: I love the fried chicken here. They know what they're doing. Perfect after a few dabs at Barbary Coast down the way on Mission.
author: Jumping J.

description: Nice little restaurant. Food and service were amazing. Definitely worth a try, if you want to experience Filipino food.
author: Niklas S.

description: I'm not the biggest filipino food fan but I do love a good tapa and this place did it pretty well, the meat was mostly lean without much gristle. Garlic rice was on point. Sunny side up egg still had uncooked egg white.
author: Sujan P.

description: I don't like filipino food, but this place is pretttty good! Service is great, even when it's late and they are about to close. They do run out of a lot of things as closing nears, but whatever they do have left is usually good and eatable. Love getting dessert here as well!
author: Rebecca J.

description: I would not recommend the daily special lechon kawali dish. It was basically large pieces of fat with very little meat. This is a huge no-no in Filipino cooking. The sisig however, was not bad and I did enjoy the lumpia.
author: Zara H.

description: Space is small but it's good. The food is as good as the one in Daly City. If only they would have a bigger space, this deserves more stars!
author: Jan Carlo G.

description: Phenominal food, setting and service! Go.  Try it!  This is a true gem in the city.
author: John B.

description: A have to try in SF. GOOD FOOD. Good people. Good spot. Happy restaurant. If you enjoy small happy place to eat some fantastic food please go this place.
author: Yifei W.

description: Myself, Tim, Reed and Lee want our ashes to be scattered here upon our demise. Seriously. It is that good. The customer service is I N C R E D I B L E (love to Patrick) and it's honestly so great to come support a place based on amazing food and filled with great people. We have literally eaten there three times within 24 hours before. We come here every weekend. Whenever we have a friend from out of town we take them here and they will still text us months later craving the food here. Tselogs we love you, and will probably see you later today
author: Ruvi F.

description: Best Chicken Sisig I've ever had. If you're ever in the city and crave some yummy filipino food, make your way to here! Small little restaurant with bar-like seating. My friends and I were about to go to the Daly City one when we saw there was one 5 min. from the Metreon where we were at. Great decision! Will come back again to try the other specials
author: Jennilyn Y.

description:
VERY TASTY!
I'm no expert on Filipino food-I've had lumpia (who hasn't?), chicken adobo (I was in the Navy, common meal), and a few basics here and there. I happened upon this gem and had to try it out. I was intrigued by the idea that SPAM is a food item, and wanted to try their meatloaf made with Spam. Apparently everything is served with a nice scoop of garlic rice with a perfectly fried egg, which is a delicious dish on it's own, and worth the price of the dish. The place is small, as indicated by other reviews, it's like walking into a small bar. Not suitable for large groups, or anything formal or particularly organized. You and a couple/few friends? Sure. The decor/furnishings are very nice and modern for the area. But very casual. Pretty sure if I came in shirtless they'd at LEAST serve me to go. Very friendly crew, the vibe is as awesome as the food. I really felt like I was with family. It's a rare connection in a restaurant, can't put a finger on it! 
I'll definitely be back.
Try delivery via PostMates for a great alternative!
author: Richard V.

description: Chicken Sisig-sizzling is ridiculously good. Excellent hole-in-the-wall Philippino restaurant. Don't let the sketchiness of the Tenderloin scare you away!
author: Rio L.

description:
This place is a wonderful addition to the tenderloin. Although I am sad that it took the place of Kare-Kan (Japanese curry restaurant before Tselogs) I still have so much love for this place. The location is perfect because it is different than all the Indian and pizza joints around jones street. 

The food here taste almost exactly the same as the original Tselogs in Daly City. Score! Don't have to travel so far just for some sisisilog. I recommend that and their lumpia. I bet their other stuff are good as well. 

The workers here are super friendly and considerate. Thanks for an awesome experience Tselogs, I will be back soon!
author: Jennifer S.

description: Ate there with friends who say it's one of the best. Turns out I got sick from eating their food. Maybe they didn't cook their food all the way? I thought something tasted a little off when I had their longsilog but I ate it anyways since the portion was small. I'm sorry but make sure you cook your food right because unless if you want to call in sick for work the next day this place is the spot!
author: Mark D.

description: I decided to try Tselogs after a recommendation from my fave Soulection DJ, Sosupersam. Since she's half Filipino, she knows her comfort food and whoa, the Chicken Sisig is for real. It's served on a sizzling plate with egg, rice and lemon on the side. It's not a huge portion, but left me comfortably full and was delicious. Service was attentive, friendly and I love that they are rocking stickers from David Choe and Upper Playground. I will most definitely be back and want to try that OG Daly City location too.
author: Kiran U.

description: First time to try Filipino food. This is good! The place is so small and the stools aren't terribly comfortable, but the food is worth it. We chose the Chicken Susie-sizzling. Yum! A sizzling plate of a saucy sweetish chicken to go along with a mound of garlic rice with a fried egg on top. It's really good. If you want something quick and casual without touristy vibe this fits the bill nicely.
author: Jo D.

description:
I go to the Tselogs in Daly City often but was closer to this location. 

Occupation size is quite small but from past experiences the food is always good, especially the Chicken Sisig.

My only criticism is during my last visit I did not realize until 1 bite in that my food had dead flies on it. I was professional and asked the waitress to come to me so I could tell her in private. The issue was that she had the audacity to tell me that the flies may have come from outside. In my head I thought "there's no way two flies could have come in the restaurant, landed on my egg and died". The professional thing to have done was immediately ask if I wanted a new plate rather than blaming me for being sat next to the door. 

Tip: if there's any bugs on a customers food, don't blame them. Offer excellent customer service and give them a new plate and apologize, since it is the customer that's paying to eat your food!
author: Reymark R.

description: Okay seriously!!! I love both locations. I'm not even Filipino but all this great delicious home made food makes me wish I was! Ahaha. I love the chicken sisig and how they serve it on a sizzling plate. I personally like to scramble my egg in there when I first get my plate and add some lime to it. I also order the arroz caldo with some lumpias ahaha! And the list goes on. You guys have to stop by and check it out. The only thing I would say about this place is that it needs more chairs lol. Kinda tight space but the food is so worth the wait!
author: Margarita V.

description: Really good food, nice modern atmosphere, and personable serving staff. sisigsilog was fantastic! The tocilog was really good too. The prices are affordable. The coffee has a great taste, and free refills! :). Music was great too! Really enjoyed it.
author: Daniel W.

description:
Oh my gosh! So excited to try Filipino eatery anywhere!
Ordered lunpia Shanghai,tocilog, tapsilog, lechon kawali, and arroz caldo. Each item is an insult to classic favorite Filipino cuisines. If only we weren't hungry I would asked my family to get up and leave. Still pay for the food but leave it barely eaten. You call it tocino? Grounded??!!Tapa? Cut in cubes???!! Lechon kawali? Bland and greasy? Arroz caldo supposedly ... But got a chicken... Okay okay this one even though it's not fresh and was pre-cooked it was tasty with a dose of msg. Even lets say other items had msg it's an insult to the purpose of adding msg. The Shanghai tasted so bad a like rotten pork we all had tummy ache afterward. 
And what's with the gloves??? What is the purpose of wearing the gloves when you are touching EVERYTHING. REALLY EVERYTHING???? 
I guess diners have no choice when they want some Filipino foods when they can't either cook or or don't have time to cook. It seems everything in this eatery are pre-cooked nothing fresh. Also using the rags to clean up for  EVERYTHING.... EVERYTHING ???!!!
Okay... I will be nice and say Staffs were nice though. But I came to eat good quality food which is lacking not for the staff.
author: E S.

description: Great place serving Filipino food at a decent price.   Had the sisig and lumpia and both were great.   I definitely plan on coming back.
author: Shawn A.

description:
We ordered take out, and service was great. So much tselog options, LOVE it.

My BF ordered the hot dogsilog, and he liked it.

I ordered the combo chicken sisigsilog plus cornbisilog, it was good but the sauce caught me a little off guard. I can't quite put my finger ok it, but it had a strange after taste for me. Cornbisilog was yummy. Garlic rice was on POINT. 

Both our eggs were slightly overcooked.

What was noteworthy was the palabok. So delicious. Sauce was good. They use the very thin palabok noodles. Glad we ordered this to try, cause it was probably our favorite order.
author: Melissa O.

description: finally an authentic filipino food sizzling chicken sisig is the best. Been here in america for 3 years highly recommendable if you want filipino food
author: Mark V.

description:
Chicken Sisig was decent. Very flavourful, texture was pretty good. Wouldn't mind a bit more crispy but not the end of the world.
Garlic rice could use more garlic, but that might be an acquired taste?
Tocino was not even bacon? Also pretty bland; could definitely have used more spicing and less food coloring. I would recommend against ordering if you like tocino.
author: Jon S.

description: First time trying Filipino food. Great first choice, clean cheap and a good setting. A little difficult to find, fyi it's a hole in the wall. Totally worth it to .
author: Steven R.

description: Solid food choice! The person working in the front today recommended the chicken sisigsilog, chicken adobo, and the lechon kawali and we enjoyed all of those dishes.  The chicken sisigsilog was definitely my favorite though! The staff working there was friendly and welcoming.  Can't wait to come back here on my next San Fran trip
author: P M.

description: My intuitions were right..this place isn't that good. The restaurant is small and has less than 10 seats available. I ordered the corned beef hash as recommended by some yelpers. I did not like it that much. It was too salty for my taste. The garlic fried rice was not as flavorful as well. I thought it was a bit pricey compared to superstar. Customer service was good though.
author: Carmen L.

description: So, so happy they opened a location in SF. I was shocked there were so many seats available during lunch rush, but I guess Filipino food's best kept secret hasn't gotten out yet to the hipsters of SF. For great prices and filling portions, you just can't beat Tselog's.
author: Nathan Q.

description: Worth the drive circling the block looking for parking!! Like Home cooking my mom used to make! Go here for that Filipino fix! IT'S ALL delicious
author: BJ G.

description: First time trying Pilipino food. Very tasty! The beef tapsilog is so good!!! Just the food is a little too salty to me. There is not a lot of space inside, but the food worth 5 star!
author: Xin G.

description: This is our favorite spot to eat when we're in the city. The chicken sisig-sizzling is delicious. So much flavor!
author: Melanie L.

description:
Solid Filipino food at a good price. Real small but always busy. Ordered Lumpia appetizer, mango juice, and lechon tselog which was garlic rice with a fried egg and tomato slice on top. Cost 20 bucks plus tip. 

Service is friendly and fast. They let us sample B4 we ordered.
author: Joe B.

description:
A very convenient spot for when you're craving filipino food in the city. It's only 3 blocks away from Union Square!

My Favorites are the Chicken Sisigsilog & Paressilog

very cool very swag i like it
author: John C.

description: The sizzling chicken is amazing, until you squeeze some lemon juice on it then it transforms into pure heaven!
author: Haroon L.

description: Very sketchy neighborhood.  It is a little place with very good and authentic Filipino food.  Love this place!!  I could eat that chicken sig till I die!!!
author: Rodney A.

description: I really liked and loved the food, staff is very friendly and accomodating except to the asian lady who has attitude!
author: Jholor S.

description: A little slice of filipino comfort food in the heart of the Tenderloin. Authentic taste at a reasonable price. Will definetly frequent this place..
author: Raymund D.

description: When I heard this place opened in SF (esp near my workplace), I got really excited. Finally got to try it and had their sisigsilog (chicken sisig + silog) and it was great! This place is tiny but I like it! The seating is right in front of the kitchen area so you see them make your food. The workers/cooks/chef here are nice too! Definitely will be back to try their other silogs! Also, you can get a second protein/meat option for an additional 2.99! Def do that if you're hungry!!!
author: Vincent C.

description: I have been eating at their Mission location since they first opened and I got so excited when I heard they opened this location on Jones!  Now I have somewhere to go for a quick, delicious, affordable meal when I'm in the city!  This space is much smaller than their first location but the food is just as good!  My favorite is their chicken sisig and buko pie! Always hits the spot!
author: As C.

description: Delicious and affordable. The chicken tselog and purple cake were absolutely awesome.
author: Danny L.

description: This place is great! Staff are very friendly,  and the portions are large. I loved all the dishes, the beef tapsilog was delicious! The sisigsilog was amazing too!
author: Joseph K.

description: The food is awesome. My bud has a beef dish and I ate a vegetarian noodle plate and we were both in happy land. It's a very nice looking place too and the neighborhood is fun.
author: Eric M.

description: Loved the tocilog over there and awesome that the staff taught me to dip the meat in white vinegar. Many perfect bites to be had with the dipped meat, garlic rice, and egg yolk. Also really enjoyed the chill playlist they had running through the speakers. Can't wait to go back.
author: andy l.
